description:
Arnhem Central is a large urban plan development that consists of diverse programmes which together form one vibrant transport hub. This cluster forms one of the main thresholds into Arnhem. To ensure a lively station area throughout the whole day, we incorporated a carefully considered mix of programmes including shops, offices, housing and a cinema complex.

UNStudio developed the overall masterplan of the station area as well as the individual components. These include, among others, the transfer hall, train platforms, Park and Rijn Towers, car and bicycle parking, the Willems Tunnel and a bus terminal.

The compact stacking of programmes enabled triple ground use. Passenger flows for six different modes of transport are organised by the central transfer terminal. Here, a large twisting central column enables a day lit, open hall that forms the heart of the station and guides foot, bicycle, car, bus, trolley-bus and train traffic along its way.
title: Arnhem Central Masterplan
External Team:
Videos
Nielson & Claus, Studio Halfvol

Awards
European Concrete Award 2016, Arnhem Central Station
Blueprint Award 2016, Commended
Architizer A+Awards 2016 (Masterplan and Transfer Terminal)
The Heuvelink Architecture Prize 2016, Public Choice
Concrete Award 2015 (Transfer Terminal)
Roof of the Year 2015 (Transfer Terminal)
European Steel Design Award 2013 (Platforms)
National Steel Prize, Utility Building 2012 (Platforms)
ANWB Award 2005, Best Designed Parking Garage (Car park)
concepts:
Transfer Hall, 2015
The openness of the interior provides clear sight lines. Therefore comparatively little wayfinding signage was needed for the transfer hall.

Platform Tunnel
Daylight from the platforms becomes a wayfinding device in the passenger tunnel.

Platform Roofs, 2012
A new fourth platform was added to accommodate growing passenger numbers in Arnhem. Additionally, all of the platform roofs have been replaced.

Bus Terminal, 2002
The new identity of the station area acknowledges Arnhem’s regional significance. With its incorporated terminals for regional and local buses, the station area forms the main entrance to the city.

Car Park, 2002
The car park is a column-free structure with integrated colour-coded wayfinding and deep V-walled stairwells that bring daylight to the underground.
In compact, mixed-use complexes like Arnhem Central, it is essential that transitory spaces are as equally considered as spaces dedicated to longer stay programmes.

Park and Rijn Towers, 2005
Visibly recognizable on the horizon the Park and Rijn office towers mark Arnhem’s transportation hub and assimilate several public functions of the transfer hall at ground level.

Willems Tunnel, 1999
The Willems Tunnel directs cars and buses either into Arnhem Central’s parking garage or towards the edge of the city centre.

The twist “unifies the whole confluence of different modes of transportation coming together into an exhilarating celebration of movement, shot through with light.
Aaron Betsky, ARCHITECT Magazine Online, 2016
http://www.architectmagazine.com/design/buildings/moving-through-arnhem-station_o
Programme: Masterplan, Transfer hall, Underground parking, Bus terminal, Two office towers, Bicycle storage, Railway platforms

description:
The Mercedes-Benz Museum is a cultural landmark that unites the past, present and future of this legendary car. Located beside Mercedes-Benz’s factory in Stuttgart-Untertürkheim, the building stands like a new gateway to the city.

The museum offers visitors a journey through time. Two chronological routes follow a double helix structure, descending and intertwining along the gallery spaces. Spiralling around a spectacular central atrium, one path winds through the vehicle collection displays; the other through historical exhibits. As the routes intersect, exciting spatial configurations, cross-references and shortcuts emerge within the various displays.
title: Mercedes-Benz Museum
External Team:
Awards
Hugo-Häring Preis 2009
Architekturpreis Beton 2008
German Design Prize 2008
Architekturpreis 2007
Ingenieurbau Preis 2006
1822-Kunstpreis 2003
concepts:
The Void
The exhibition areas are structured around a central triangular atrium that rises as an open core through the building. This impressive void frames the inner workings of the building and offers changing perspectives of the interior as visitors weave their way through the exhibitions.

Alternating between open and enclosed the exhibition spaces are linked by the intersecting, spiral routes. This routing enables visitors to view the exhibits from near and far, as well as from above, when descending into the gallery spaces.

In case of fire, smoke is extracted from the building through a novel ‘tornado’ smoke elimination system developed especially for the museum. Smoke is sucked from the open gallery spaces into the void and then released via 144 air nozzles at the top of the atrium.

The Twist
The twist forms a striking transformative element throughout the building. As a key load-bearing structure, the twist supports exhibition levels spanning more than 100 feet without intermediate columns.

The top surface of each twist becomes a circulation ramp that seamlessly transitions between the staggered gallery plateaus.

“You could, finally, name the 2006 Mercedes Benz Museum in Stuttgart, by the Dutch firm UNStudio, as proof that 21st-century temples to automotive design can be meaningful pieces of architecture, sophisticated enough to hold their own against the cars they hold, and unapologetic crowd pleasers at the same time.”

Christopher Hawthorne, Los Angeles Times, 2015
http://www.latimes.com/entertainment/arts/la-et-cm-petersen-automotive-museum-review-20151124-column.html
Programme: Car museum, shop, restaurant, offices, auditorium

description: Cockle bay is as an enhanced waterfront for gathering and celebration. Cockle bay is a unique addition to Sydney as a 'stepping stone' between Harbor and City that is connected, diverse, energized and natural. The active public domain repairs the connection between the city and the harbor, maximises green public space for a sense of connection to nature. This composes a lifestyle, retail and business destination that anticipates the future of life and work. UNStudio develops strong, clear and intuitive connections from major city routes that step down via landscapes from the city to the harbor. These routes carve out a diversity of functional park spaces for differing functions including leisure and wellness activities. The aim is to prioritise the creation of active green and open public space along main connective routes.
title: Cockle Bay
UNStudio Team: Ben van Berkel and Caroline Bos
concepts:
Sydney’s communal life
Cockle Bay Park plays a social role in Sydney’s communal life. The design proposal maximises connected open public areas in the podium, designed for a diversity of uses. This amenity is ample for the tower above that houses a commercial function of offices. The sense of place established at the podium levels continues sensitively throughout the vertical connection with multiple vistas into the lower tower -continuing the overriding theme of connection. This connection is people to nature, park to tower and people to people. The tower form enhances connections through consideration of views, sunlight, slenderness, verticality and context.

The concept of 'stepping stones' fractures the scale of the tower; the sculpted, slightly shifting segmentation in the foreground corner makes the volume appear both slim and vertically appropriate in its context. The tower form pivots and is wedged to include terraces, which strengthen this connection with nature and the surrounding waterfront context through privileged views.

There is also an exploration of social connections through the design of the towers. This connection between people strengthens through formal and informal social spaces with experience-led programming including leisure and social wellness spaces.

description: Central Place is a vibrant extension of the Western Sydney gateway area in the heart of Gadigal Country. The programme of UNStudio's design includes a novel public, retail, and workplace experience for the future generation of tech citizens. Here, we deepen the core brief to consider the well-being and health of occupants. Connection to the natural environment allow well-being benefits to be nurtured, cross-connecting different vertical gardens and villages up into and throughout the towers to provide health benefits.
title: Central Place
External Team:
Buchan
Bruce Shaw, Alex Dickson, Harvey Male, Valerie Mack, Jimmy Bolger

Design Architect: UNStudio and Buchan
Landscape architect, Urban Realm: Aspect studio
Retail Vision & Design Curation: Seventh Wave
Indigenous Design and Engagement: Balarinji
Facade engineering: Priedemann
Social and Environmental Design: Atelier Ten
Structural, Civil and Building Services: Arup
Planning Consultant: Urbis
concepts:
Campus-like design
The design for Central Place focusses on a campus-like design model that fosters seamless connectivity: the public domain of the Western Gateway sub-precinct extends from the outside physically and conceptually into the “working lounge” within the podium. This public domain extends further, via voids and gardens, into the tower spaces. The frontage adjacent to henry Deane Plaza and Lee Street Frontage is active and full of retail. This creates life and activity in the project as a whole and invites the public into the activities of the office. In this way, the building becomes a knowledge-sharing mechanism, a technological souq, sharing both within organizations, the public and the city.

Sustainability
The precinct and tower are very considered, reaching high levels of sustainable outcomes. The towers are net zero carbon, with integrated PV panels and passive design as a building block to reduce demand. The design approach to the facade uses analysis to inform the configuration, where a combination of transparency and opacity are used to maximize views, while reducing embodied carbon, cost, and maintenance associated with external shading systems. The outdoor terraces provide a range of social spaces, an urban oasis that frames the surrounding urban views with lush greenery.

description: UNStudio's design for Castle Towers ‘breaks open’ the box of traditional suburban shopping malls, through physical form and retail mix. The proposal celebrates and amplifies outdoor space, splitting the porosity of the mall and adding porosity to the scheme. A generosity in amenity and shelter allows the users to linger and socialise, amplifying Castle Towers as a community Hub for the wider district.
title: Castle Towers
UNStudio Team: Wouter de Jonge and Jan Schellhoff
External Team:
Design Architect: UNStudio
Interior Design: UDS
Executive Architect: The Buchan Group
Retail Vision & Design Curation: Seventh Wave London
MEP, VT and ESD: ADP Consulting
Structural and civil engineering services: BG&E
Landscape Design: Context
Facade engineering: Inhabit Group
Building Compliance: Philip Chun Associates
Lighting Design: Seam Design & Point of View
concepts:
A celebration of the outdoors
In our design for Castle towers, we introduce terraces to provide active frontage with views to nearby Blue Mountains from the peak of Castle Hill. The skylight roof and internalised spaces allow for more formal Mall-like space, but the high integration of greenery, stepped terracing within create a more open and communal experience. The roof encases an interior setting that captures vast views towards the Blue Mountains. The celebration of the outdoors is extended through the use of natural elements in materiality: warm stone, concrete and timber. The light is filtered through the skylight through lamella, exploring an architectural concept of a ‘veil’ that filters the light as it enters the interior. This light is detailed but diffuse to captivate, creating an enduring and unique experience. This refined architectural concept defines a district as elevated, timeless and exclusive.

Re-imagining retail experience
Castle Towers also challenges the nature of suburban shopping through the retail mix and offering. Castle Towers offers a diverse series of curated brands and extensive food and beverage. These brands vary from the mainstream to the luxury, focused primarily on the unique and exclusive. These brands arrange around a diverse form; that celebrates altering modes of shopping spaces. A series of malls and connective spaces, open out into series of pavilions that form the ‘eastern village’. Within this village, a large food and beverage program and lively events sustain the life of the community. Outdoor and indoor nodes perform experiential relief, interest and gathering for users across the mall and village while creating cohesion between the different shopping spaces.
Programme: Mixed-use retail, food and beverage, event and educational, residences and office

description:
UNStudio’s design for The Bridge high-rise development in Warsaw, Poland, aims to address issues surrounding how new building developments can perform in an urban context in order to create a framework for a sustainable future. With its spatial organisation, the design strategically connects the public spaces around it, whilst also re-inventing the city’s connection to its heritage.

Designed for Ghelamaco and in collaboration with local partner Projekt Polsko-Belgijska Pracownia Architektury, ‘The Bridge’s’ spatial architecture strategically connects the skyscraper with the public spaces around it.

The Bridge connects to the city’s historic heritage by blending the historic Bellona building with the new tower, making it a one-of-a-kind composition in the Polish market.
title: The Bridge
External Team:
Advisors
Structure and MEP: WSP Poland
Local Architect/Architect of record: PPBPA (Projekt Polsko Belgijska Pracownia Architektury)
Lighting design: Licht&Soehne
Green design: Moss
concepts:
Sustainability
UNStudio’s design for The Bridge is equipped with environmentally friendly solutions and a smart operating system. Developed and implemented by Ghelamco, this operation system makes efficient access management possible and provides safety solutions in case of an epidemic, such as virucidal UV lamps in the elevators and air tunnels.

The Bridge is the first commercial property in Central and Eastern Europe to have received SmartScore and WiredScore certificates for sustainability. The building is also set to be BREEAM-, Well-, Green Building Standard- and Building Without Barriers certified.

Public activation
The Bridge offers 47,000 square metres of office space and provides approximately 280 parking spaces, bicycle facilities and chargers for electric cars, alongside a special parking lot for electric bicycles and electric scooters.

A small park next to Grzybowska Street replaces parking spaces that previously took up the location. As such, a green public square leads visitors to the entrance of The Bridge. An additional entrance to the square also leads through the gate of the residence at 73 Grzybowska Street.

description:
UNStudio’s design for the Kirchberg Valley envisions a state of the art, DGMB Platinum inclusive office campus that aims to create a lively environment for all; for the employees of both main tenants of the campus, ESM and Luxembourg State, but also for the public, the visitors, the passengers, the neighbors, the daily commuters of Kirchberg.

Located at the intersection of the green axis of rue Alcide de Gasperi East-West and the pedestrian North-South crossing, the Kirchberg Valley becomes an important anchor within the urban fabric of the neighbourhood. As such, it also establishes a prototype for development, one that promotes a healthy lifestyle for its employees.

UNStudio’s design is about inspiration, connectivity, collaboration, productivity, attraction, wellbeing, engagement, safety and adds value for the people and the organisations across multiple fields. Here, flexibility is also taken into consideration in order to deliver a human-centred workplace that meets current and future demands.

As such, Kirchberg Valley becomes a beacon for the values of ESM and Luxembourg State, embodying their aspirations and ambitions.
title: Administration building for the European Stability Mechanism and the Luxembourg State
External Team:
Advisors
Key Local Architect, Local Cost Consultant, Waste Management: BalliniPitt Architectes Urbanistes
Local MEP and Structural Engineering: SGI
Structure, MEP, Innovation & Sustainability Engineering: Buro Happold
Landscape: Felixx
Local Fire Life Safety, Vertical Transportation: Secolux
Hospitality: Enbiun
Visualisations: Moare, UNStudio
keywords: The forest as centre and sustainability
concepts:
The Kirchberg Valley Concept
The site of Kirchberg Valley is developed around the idea of maximising the public green space. To do so, we kept the footprint of all three buildings to a minimum, which additionally lowers land consumption and local impact while ensuring the provision of a very efficient floor organisation.

The design invites the public to walk through and experience the site, to use it during their daily routine, and as a place of rest. In order to achieve this, we needed to ensure the site’s permeability. Rather than creating a barrier following the plot boundary, over half of the site, that which is fronting the axis of rue Alcide de Gasperi, is open and accessible to the public. This open space is activated throughout the day with a series of carefully planned programmes that attracts users and ensure the livability of the area.

The new public space is set to become a lively and healthy environment that will benefit the city. A public space rich in vegetation and dense trees will be accessible to pedestrians and bring a boost of biodiversity and oxygen into the district. This green corridor will connect rue Alcide de Gasperi to the north-west side of the plot through a biodiverse promenade.

All three main building volumes are centrally located opening the remaining perimeter to the public. The three volumes are specifically spaced in order improve light conditions. Three main plazas are created along the perimeter of the site, defining major accessibility points and acts as a major connector to the entire site.

Courtyards have also been introduced to improve daylight conditions, and are lifted up along the main plazas to create entrances. The two main volumes are designed to extend vertically in order to improve solar exposure. The tower of both main buildings leans gently towards the edge of the site, emphasising the urban corners and the effect of a valley.

The forest as centre and sustainability
Our design approach differs greatly from the usual urban greening; instead of creating a building and simply adding natural elements around it, we propose to create an autonomous central forest - a green heart of the new development at the plateau de Kirchberg. The buildings will then be integrated into this green, creating a diversity of conditions for the landscape.

Inserting densely planted, small-scale ecosystem will be very effective in carbon sequestration as well as have a cooling effect on the surrounding urban context, and offers refuge to variety of animal species. We also encourage planting a large variety of species, which will help regenerate the soil.

Our design also features green roofs that improve the building’s thermal performance, offer green space for leisure, reduce the urban heat island effect, and contribute to CO2 sequestration.

The ESM and Luxembourg buildings are designed with a holistic sustainability strategy in mind, considering environmental, ecological and sociocultural spheres of sustainability, while also considering process and site-related measures, striving for the highest DGNB rating. The strategy rests on three key pillars: measures for a low-carbon footprint in operation and construction, circularity and flexibility on all of the buildings’ structural and technical systems, and integration of strategies to enhance health and wellbeing of the users.

Office Concept
All three buildings of the Kirchberg Valley follow the same underlying design principles and can accommodate the same programme and layouts, be it boxed or open plan offices, or a mix of both. The position of the cores, the construction and the sprinkler system and general distances are resilient and allow for future flexibility.

Flexibility / Long life design
The project was designed in a way that allows components to be removed or deconstructed in the future and reconditioned for reuse. At the same time, the floors are made of elements that can be separated, which results in a flexible and resilient building.

Employee Well-being
A healthy and inspiring work environment will contribute to the mental well-being of the employees, through stimulating social interaction, prioritising comfort, integrating natural elements and using healthy materials. All of these stimulate healthy behaviours, leading to an increase in productivity and a reduction in sick leave.
Client: Le gouvernement du Grand-Duché de Luxembourg, Administration des bâtiments publics

description:
'Transform' is an exhibition held at the Dornbirn Light Forum that highlights UNStudio and the Zumtobel Group's collaboration on the 31st annual report of the Zumtobel Group, which was designed by UNStudio, Ben van Berkel and the graphic design duo Bloemendaal & Dekkers.

Transform - the annual report is a visual reflection on the topic of transformation in architecture and the built environment highlights the creative processes of our work at UNStudio over the last three decades. 

In these rapidly changing times, we increasingly embrace change and innovation. In all facets of our lives, we deviate, modify, shift and pivot to challenge and disrupt long accepted norms. Transformation has also always been a central facet of the architectural profession, the built environment and of the work of UNStudio.
title: Transform Exhibition - Zumtobel Group’s Light Forum
concepts:
Floating light images
The temporary exhibition includes an immersive interpretation of transformation as analysed in the annual report and is staged using Zumtobel’s lighting technology.

At UNStudio, we believe in architecture that provides powerful new experiences, which are derived from conceptual models and theoretical ideas. As such, integrated systems where the experience, geometry and functionality of the building merge and become fully synthesised are developed.

Our design for the exhibition Transform is a spatial interpretation of such system thinking. Here, the mathematical Fibonacci sequence, which is frequently observed in natural forms and phenomena, is used to enable an immersive ‘mindscape’ and layering of images; a variety of altering visual connections that allude to both the creative process and the underlying DNA that can be found in our work.

Coloured light and different gradients are used to frame the images that are applied to an ultralight, translucent fabric to give the viewer an immersive experience. The light frames, which float in the space, are offset from one another, while their translucency allows the colours of the individual images to mix. Depending on the combination of colour and gradient lighting, graphics and text appear or disappear, creating varying scenarios that give the viewer the feeling of being immersed in UNStudio's design processes.

Versatile inspirations for panel talk
At the opening and reflecting upon the central topic of transformation, Alexander Gutzmer, author and Head of the Center for Corporate Architecture at the Quadriga University of Applied Sciences in Berlin, moderated a panel that spotlighted UNStudio's founder and principal architect, Ben van Berkel, Ines Goldbach, Director Kunsthalle Basel and, and artist Cendra Polsner.

Alongside sharing their thoughts on the annual report, the guests reflected on the role of architecture in the current transformation of cities and society. The discussion placed a special focus on the mutual stimulation of architecture and art.

description:
For the Société Nationale des Chemins de Fer Luxembourgeois (CFL)’s new headquarters, UNStudio developed a human-centred urban campus that promotes the connectivity between employees, citizens and tourists. Les Jardins de la Gare expands upon the existing building to include more greenery and an accessible roof.

Here, flexibility and modularity played an integral role in this regenerative project. The office space offers a number of configurations that is made possible through the use of modularity which was employed in the facade and the structure as well as the interior organisation and compartmentalisation. With this flexibility, we are also able to contribute to the health and well-being of all employees by offering them the opportunity for social gatherings, the exchange of knowledge in a space of daylight and greenery.
title: CFL Luxembourg
External Team:
Advisors
Key Local Architect, Local Cost Consultant, Waste Management: BalliniPitt Architectes Urbanistes
Local MEP and Structural Engineering: SGI
Acoustics Engineering: ATECH Acoustic Technologies
Sustainability: Except
Landscape: Felixx
Local Fire Life Safety, Vertical Transportation: Secolux

Visualisations
Moare
UNStudio
concepts:
Office renovation
In UNStudio’s design, a building extension along the railway, with offices on the upper floors, public spaces on the ground floor and a green roof extends the existing CFL headquarters. Red awnings, inspired by the roof of the existing building, unify the two volumes and function as a connecting thread.
A green interior courtyard, reserved for pedestrians, makes a physical link between the Place de la Gare and the Rue du Chemin de Fer, whilst becoming a new main entrance hall for employees. Meanwhile, the station square remains open to the public, and a third employee-only access is located in rue de Fort Neipperg. Employee cars are parked in the underground car park equipped with a car lift.
The main volume of the extension descends in stages, expressing the interior configuration in the façade. This movement highlights the vertical characteristics of the existing building, and maintains its character as the central point in the development.

While the space on the roof of the old building made space for solar panels, the roof of the new volume is more accessible, and has the potential to provide building users with a moment to relax; it offers the opportunity to take a break during the day, meet colleagues for a coffee, a place to sit and enjoy the breeze. Green roofs, as well as the interior and exterior courtyards offer different types of relaxation areas for employees and visitors.

Façade
The facade draws inspiration from the existing building in terms of form and appearance, while applying a double facade approach in the extension volume. The fully glazed double-skin facade in front of the existing building highlights CFL’s history. The new extension provides year-round thermal comfort for the occupants, while movable louvers built into the cavity prevent the facade from overheating in the summer.

They also increase the insulation values and allow daylight deep into the interior, which contributes to the optimisation of energy consumption and the improvement of the overall interior climate and its acoustic performance.

Sustainability
UNStudio’s design proposal uses an integrated sustainable approach, taking into account the well-being of users and the environment, both in construction and in operation. For this, we designed a building ‘metabolism’, in which all essential resources are demonstrated to work towards an optimised building concept. The advantage of this approach is the synergy between the different functions, allowing for reduced costs, flexibility, higher performance and efficient operations in the long term. Critical performance gains from this approach include significantly improved user well-being and environment, resulting in reduced sick days and increased productivity. Furthermore, it guarantees resilience for future changes in work and organisation and its long-term investment value.
Client: SOCIÉTÉ NATIONALE DES CHEMINS DE FER LUXEMBOURGEOIS

description:
Shenzhen, a vibrant and highly innovative city, is home to many leading and innovative corporate headquarters. UNStudio's proposal for a competition held for the design of the Shenzhen Super Headquarters Base tower C in the city outlined its concept for the Shenzhen's new work and lifestyle, alongside the future of Shenzhen city. It would not only draw visitors to the area but would set a new benchmark for technology, sustainability and lifestyle, in addition to creating value for operators and tenants.

Tower C is located within the Shenzhen Super Headquarter Base, which is at the intersection of the north-south central green axis and the east-west future spine. It is positioned as a corporate headquarters integrating office, commerce, hotel, culture, transportation and municipal services, alongside public services. In the future, it would house many corporate headquarters, international organisations and innovative start-up enterprises.

The design aims to be the new face of the district to further strengthen Shenzhen’s reputation as one of the most dynamic, innovative and prosperous emerging hot spots in the world.
title: Shenzhen Bay Headquarters Tower C
concepts:
In our design, the Super Headquarter Base would become the urban gateway to Shenzhen. It is an example for the future city, combining new models of working with cutting-edge innovation and improving local quality of life. Tower C would become the icon of the city, the global headquarters where leaders in technology and emerging businesses could come together; a place where innovation would thrive and progress be stimulated. Our design sets the example for healthier, adaptive future workspaces.
Ben van Berkel, UNStudio's Founder and Principal Architect

Synergy Hub
'Synergy Hub' is the key concept of UNStudio's design proposal for the building. Programmatically, different types of commercial and public functions are placed strategically throughout the building, engaging visitors and organizing activity flows to create a truly vertically-integrated design. The different prograes act in a symbiotic manner, supporting each other's operation and functionality and maximizing interaction between different user groups. 

The 'social spine' is the main design feature of the building. It forms the diagonal gesture that runs up each side of the tower, leading up from the base, where the Central Green Axis and the future Urban Spine intersect. As a key piece of the design, it comprises atria, networking spaces and other shared facilities for both tenants and visitors.

Our goal for the Tower C design is to create a social hub that vertically integrates work, culture and commercial functions as one mixed-use programme, while promoting new healthy and highly performative ways of working. It is a centre-oriented design that benefits from its innovation and creates an icon for Shenzhen.
Hannes Pfau, Partner and Senior Architect, UNStudio

Tower Iterations
A tailored tool was developed to analyze the different positions of tower C in the urban context. It helps to calculate the proximity of neighbouring towers, the amount of unobstructed views, the skyline, and to study the view of tower C compared with surrounding towers A and B.

The design team carried out multiple possible iterations before finally finding the position with the best view, best skyline and the least energy consumption for tower C. At the same time, the central green axis, the future city ridge, and the public transit-oriented development (TOD) intersect with each other in ‘TOD Plaza’, supporting each other harmoniously.

Multi-Plazas
In order to create a dynamic vertically integrated tower, multiple public plazas are incorporated along the tower from below to above. On the basement level, the ‘TOD Plaza’ serves as a gateway to both the site and the surroundings, and acts as a central social hub, providing visitors and the general public direct access to City Hall, the Conference Centre, and the cultural programme, as well as to the two office tower lobbies. Further up the Cultural Bridge connects the two towers, while also providing an interactive public space. The ’Crown Plaza’ is located at the top of the tower with a hotel and cultural exhibition space. As part of the digital museum of this urban destination, the ‘cultural crown’ is located on the top of the building. It is an open art centre, decorated with digital lighting, to become a shining artistic lighthouse above the city.

Zero carbon design - Healthy, future oriented working space
UNStudio’s office design of tower C is zero carbon and centered on designing for health. A healthy working space is created which benefits all employees. As much public space and meeting activity space as possible is created to maximize knowledge sharing and collaboration, while the office space is flexible to meet the ever-changing needs of the future workplace.

Active design and renewable systems were applied in the design process. This approach does not focus purely on technical applications, but also uses natural ventilation, shading and daylighting, green roofs and wastewater recycling systems, in addition to a high-performance waterside and HVAC system, which not only improves energy efficiency, but can also reduce operation and maintenance costs. The design proposal for Tower C was a future model for Shenzhen, which integrates an intelligent building system that helps resource integration and risk control.
Client: Shenzhen Bay Super Base Construction Headquarters Office（Housing and Construction Bureau of Shenzhen Municipality)
Programme: Comprehensive mixed-use development consisting of the following programmes: Grade-A Offices, 5-Star Hotel, Retail, Bus Terminal, Transport Interchange Hub, International Conference Centre, City Exhibition Hall, Smart City Centre, Tourist Centre, Post Office, Sky Cultural Space, Multi-Purpose Theatre and Multi-Purpose Exhibition and Art Space

description:
Located in Frankfurt's Europaviertel West, UNStudio's design for NION will be one of the most sustainable office buildings in Germany. This lively hybrid city district, which combines residential, work and recreational facilities, has been in continual development since 2005.

UNStudio's overall concept breaks new, sustainable ground both technically and architecturally, and incorporates ESG objectives and highly efficient, resource-saving technology. This contributes to not only promoting environmental sustainability, but also social sustainability. Here, we set to encourage collaboration, wellness and a sense of place. 

UNStudio is also working with Groß & Partner on the currently under construction FOUR project in Frankfurt, one of the most dense inner-city developments in Europe.
title: NION
External Team:
Advisors (competition phase)
Landscape: OKRA Landschapsarchitecten BV
Structure and Facade: Bollinger+Grohmann
MEP and Energy: KBP Ingenieure GmbH
Fire Protection: HHP Berlin
Local Support: Hochform Architekten Frankfurt
CGI visualisations: MOARE
concepts:
Uncompromising sustainability
The sustainable concept for NION focuses on both environmental and social sustainability. Alongside intensive greening throughout, our design employs a low-carbon load-bearing structure. Prefabricated components will be used in construction, alongside a modular supporting structure. The design further focuses on the use of sustainable, recyclable and circular construction materials. 

The sustainable concept for NION further responds intelligently to the weather and actual demand. It incorporates a photovoltaic facade, rainwater management, geothermal heating and cooling, smart building management, demand-based air conditioning and LED lighting, energy recuperating elevators, e-charging stations with intelligent load management and green and open work environments.

NION is also designed to be socially sustainable, with specific programming that encourages, communication, gathering and knowledge sharing.

Intensive greening
Greening plays a large role in the design of NION. As an integral part of the Europa-Allee urban green corridor, the site is intended to be a vehicle for greenery and biodiversity, bringing ecological benefits to the environment, while improving the microclimate and contributing to the well-being of visitors and users of the building.

The structure consists of two intersecting volumes, where the northwest and southeast corners are cut away to create a striking vertical effect, emphasised by lush greenery. 

From the green lobby, to the semi-public interior space in the base, to the green zones in the office floors, which are combined with green terraces and roof gardens. All of the spaces in NION are designed to enhance the working climate and create an exciting relationship between interior and exterior.
Programme: Office and Podium with public functions

description: 80 Collins, set at the heart of Melbourne’s lively central district, already has one benchmark on the skyline: the recognisably columned Nauru House, which was completed in 1977. On either side of this existing structure, two contemporary buildings have been designed - in a collaboration between UNStudio, Seventh Wave, Woods Bagot and Jouin Manku - to reinvigorate and respond to the cultural significance of this well-known location, taking their design cues from their notable surroundings. To the west, slotted neatly into Little Collins Street, a 100 meter tall hotel becomes a concealed gem within the cityscape, with an interplaying facade of glass and aluminium complete with restaurant, business centre, gym, swimming pool and retail space, the new hotel brings 24 hour connectivity and programmatic diversity into this dynamic location. Surrounded by history, luxury and business opportunity, these high-rise additions to the 80 Collins precinct transform this renowned address into a flexible, world class, mixed-use complex.
title: Next Hotel
External Team:
Photography
AECOM Photography by Robb Williamson
concepts:
Flexible Experience
For the hotel building, the restaurant, bar, pool, gym and other recreational amenities, which allow for a lively or relaxing experience, are arranged with spaces of varying heights on top of the lobby. The third floor lobby itself was designed as a triple height space with a transparent glass facade facing Little Collins Street. The transparency and scale of the lobby create visual and physical relief from the otherwise dense urban fabric on Little Collins Street. By contrast, design features along the facade reduce frontal views from the adjacent buildings and provide partial screening and an increased sense of privacy for guests.

Corresponding with glazing transparency and reflectivity, this strategy allows for both optimum night time and daylight conditions. Combined, these elements resolve themselves in a composition that deftly negotiates the challenges of their context and turns the 80 Collins precinct into ‘a breathing space’ in the busiest part of Melbourne.

Considered Design
Following a series of collaborative workshops with a third party review, the attributes of the existing 80 Collins scheme were enhanced by the design team to maximise the site’s potential, creating a site specific building that becomes a world class address. The design team also closely engaged with the hotel operator to ensure the programmatic mix and operational considerations of the site had been addressed to present the best design outcome. Cognizant of the calibre of the project, these workshops and collaborations elevated the stature of the project. The massing is at once private and intimate, and open and generous - amounting to a proposal that will become an important contribution to Melbourne’s urban life.

Hotel Facade
Various degrees of exposure and reflection are also applied to the design and materialisation of the hotel facade. Aluminium and glass were selected for their reflective qualities, along with a construction logic that ensures crisp forms. Design features such as vertical cuts bring daylight into the hotel corridors, while at night these cuts are lit - highlighting the location and connections of all public functions within the building. The dark coloration of the frontage also makes the building distinct among the surrounding buildings.

To overcome the context and proximity with neighbouring buildings the hotel facade is designed to make optimal use of daylight, redirect views from within the hotel and offer guests a sense of privacy. The design of the facade on the upper floors considers the introverted nature of the guest rooms by overlaying an articulated skin of solid folding panels with glazed inserts. These features guide guests’ views eastward across the 80 Collins plot and up Little Collins Street, creating ‘introverted hotel rooms’ as opposed to the ‘extrovert amenities’ on the lower floors, which open up their more communal programmes towards the street-scape.
Programme: Hotel: Hotel Room + Support + Amenities (Restaurant, Business Center, Lobby, Gym + Pool)

description:
Inspired by FlySolo’s mission to empower children of all abilities to take an active role in society, and as part of UNStudio’s diverse efforts to give back to the community, UNStudio worked with FlySolo to create the design for a dedicated pediatric medical centre in Beijing; a unique approach to rehabilitation in China and one that reimagines the healthcare experience from the perspective of both children and their parents.

The design is home to flexible physical, occupational and speech therapy rooms, as well as shared doctors’ and consultation offices. Here, UNStudio considered the human experience in rehabilitation medicine to help patients gain access to a diverse range of innovative therapies. 

In order to promote positive mental health, the interior incorporates a soothing palette of colours and sweeping gestures, inspired by nature and favorite children’s book illustrations.
title: FlySolo Rehabilitation Medical Centre
External Team:
Construction Management: China Academy of Building Research
Consultants: Shanghai CIMA Engineering Consulting Co. Ltd.
Contractors: Bang Tai Construction Co. Ltd., InDeco, Zhi Shang Construction Co. Ltd.
concepts:
A sustainable and flexible interior
Both the interior design concept and the circulation for the FlySolo Rehabilitation Medical Centre revolve around sustainability and flexibility. Most materials used in the interior are LEED certified building materials. A warm and humanising rehabilitation experience is fostered with a strong focus on the individual patient and family journey from diagnosis to treatment.

Flexible functionality was a central feature of the design. To achieve this, UNStudio, alongside FlySolo’s doctors, therapists, and family advisory committee, considered numerous possible layouts based on maximising the required uses of the overall space, with the aim of striking a balance between the physical, the psychological and the social.

Due to the incorporation of flexible partition walls, the room layouts can be adjusted over time and customised for the changing needs of the Centre in the future.

A healing sanctuary
The needs of the child patient are central to UNStudio's design, which incorporates the child’s need to play, explore, move and discover.

In the waiting areas outside of the treatment rooms, mini slides and interactive seating are incorporated in order to engage and energise. Small nooks are also provided for children to play in and to provide privacy for waiting parents and families.

Overall, a keen focus is placed on materials, space, scale, light, and circulation, while soft, bright and natural colours work to add another layer of engagement.

Beacon of hope
FlySolo’s identity as a place for uplifting children is reflected in the sweeping facade. The wave-like graphics of the interior are mirrored in the curves of the facade that frame the entrance. Here, a pearl white aluminum frame composed of intricately fabricated curved panels conveys an inspiring message of new possibility to families embarking on an emotionally challenging journey, and a welcoming gesture to the children.

Design and construction of the FlySolo Rehabilitation Medical Centre was completed during the COVID-19 pandemic despite global travel and supply chain obstacles.

description:
UNStudio's competition-winning design for Palas Residential is more than a building. It is an attempt to redefine the relationship between public and private spaces, while simultaneously serving as an example of how we can redefine the relationship between contemporary architecture and historical city centres.

Set in the heart of Iasi, heritage is always extant as the backdrop to this Romanian city's very active and lively present. Iasi combines its current status as an economic, cultural and academic powerhouse with its rich history and offers a unique and exciting place for living, working and thriving.

These singular qualities make Iasi the perfect place for a new way of living, where the past, present, and future exist in synergy.
title: Palas Residential
UNStudio Team: Stella Nikolakaki and Denis Manisali Leba
External Team: Visualisations: WAX
concepts:
Winning this competition is an amazing opportunity for UNStudio to work in such an interesting and historically charged environment. UNStudio prides itself in designing architecture with a clear story, focused on how people experience space and this urban and cultural setting offers a challenging and exciting location for us to add a new architectural experience to Iasi. Rather than ‘oneliner solutions’, we believe that inner city developments require a very contextual approach that adds value to the city for all the people.
Ben van Berkel, UNStudio's Founder and Principal Architect

A site infused with history
The Palas Residential site is located centrally, next to the Palace of Culture and numerous other churches and monuments, in one of the most culturally and historically ‘charged’ locations in Iasi. The site is located at a crossroads between the lower part of the area that is populated by small-scale residential buildings (St. Andrew’s  neighbourhood) and the higher part, which is replete with grand monuments.

This historic environment, in addition to Iasi’s exciting momentum in terms of economic, academic and cultural development, creates the perfect backdrop for this ambitious project.

The Palas Residential concept
Building the ‘Horizon’

The key drivers for the design of the Palas Residential were the integration of the new development into the city and the building of a new community that will blend into the existing social framework of the area. The main spatial gesture used to achieve this, called the ‘horizon’, is the addition of a level in the building that promotes this integration both spatially and programmatically.

The horizon is designed as a physical extension of the public space, thus bringing the city into the building and potentially offering a place for the city’s creative professionals.

This massing concept is driven by the topography of the site and by the different characteristics of the areas above and below the development. This contextual response forms the main gesture and concept for the articulation of the building in terms of both geometry and materials, as well as programme. As such, each part of the building has its own unique design, character, and programme.

Framing History
Palas Residential generates its identity from its historical location, which will also become the building's new backdrop and provide newly framed viewing perspectives.

Multiple portals are designed to frame the views to the surrounding monuments. Here, brick frames create a strong connection to the city and offer a unique identity to Palas Residential. While crossing the courtyard, residents and visitors are offered a unique perception of the city.

As such, Palas Residential becomes an active addition to the city, adding to how it is experienced in a discreet way.

Our vision is to create a space that bridges time. Palas Residential is intended to be a contemporary environment that can host quality residential spaces and public facilities, while being fully integrated into the context of the surroundings; an environment that generates its identity based on its historical framework, simultaneously becoming the new backdrop for the surrounding monuments and offering new angles and visibility perspectives for them.
Ben van Berkel, UNStudio's Founder and Principal Architect

Creating a new urban community and a healthy, sustainable and biophilic experience
Above all, Palas Residential will be inclusive. As such, a new type of cultural and flexible space is proposed as part of this bridging: a space that will create the place for a contemporary urban public.

A human-centric approach also forms the basis of the design for Palas Residential. Energy management, circularity and well-being are the primary drivers in the choice of building methods and materiality. The careful curation of green spaces with a biophilic approach is crucial for the formation of an environment that promotes health and well-being

description:
Future Perfect is a collaborative initiative driven by UNStudio that explores potential design opportunities created by combining neglected design heritage as inspiration with outdated products left over from manufacturing.

The overall aim of the concept is to create a design collection in the widest sense of the word, where both design and sustainability are approached in new ways. Rather than recycling leftover products, the concept is to repurpose them by combining, overwriting and altering the products in such a way that their original properties are respected. As a result, design inspired by heritage is translated into objects that enhance both the aesthetic and ethical values of the leftover products and the original heritage inspiration.
title: Future Perfect
concepts:
Another take on creativity, design and creating sustainable values
Future Perfect repurposes outdated products without recycling them by translating circular economy principles into methodologies and language of design. The design language draws inspiration from the heritage of textile and fashion patterns, prints and prototype collections of F.FRI (Fashion Research Italy Foundation).

Instead of using virgin materials, Future Perfect starts at the end of the manufacturing process of two project partners – Object Carpet and Kvadrat. Their waste stream and outdated leftovers, the by-products of an imperfect manufacturing process are looked at as a resource.

Inspired by this intriguing archive, the Future Perfect initiative was created by combining patterns from the archive with outdated products left over from manufacturing. The collections and objects designed in the next phases of the project will be created under the umbrella of Future Perfect and all share the same design principles, they can be realised in multiple forms: from new interior products, objects, furniture and fixtures, to visual merchandising campaigns or urban furniture, depending on the products that are reused.

A circular approach
Based on the historic fashion prints, the outdated textile and carpets, collections are brought to a new life with a circular approach minimising reproduction, recycling and concentrating on creating value by design.

The new collections created under the umbrella of Future Perfect will not be tied together by formal characteristics, but by the same design principles focused on a unique sustainable approach.

description:
The design for the newly constructed apartment interior, located in Amsterdam, aims to blend architectural form and contemporary art. The apartment acts as a backdrop and a blank canvas for the owner’s collection of contemporary art, while still articulating strong formal gestures.

All of the furniture and fixtures throughout the apartment are custom, built-in designs, which flow seamlessly from room to room and create a sense of continuation of form and programme.

The overall space (130m2) is comprised of two floors with a connecting staircase from the ground floor entrance. The lower floor contains two bedrooms with an adjoining walk in closet, while the top floor houses the living room and kitchen.

In order to fit a large amount of programme within a small buildable space, the architecture and furniture assist in blending different rooms and materials. This is achieved through the minimalism of the materials - which mainly include white and marble wall and furniture finishes - and accents of dark wood, to highlight the formal gestures.

The flooring remains light in colour throughout, through the use of continuous pine planks that line the entire apartment from end to end. All of the furniture and fixtures are customised to the specific space and function they serve, through extensive detailing and material and lighting integration. The space is then brought to life with colour accents from the movable furniture pieces and the art collection.
title: Loft 02
External Team:
Advisors
Local Executive Architect: Gietermans & Van Dijk Architecten B.V.

title: Loft 02
External Team:
Advisors
Local Executive Architect: Gietermans & Van Dijk Architecten B.V.

description:
Loft 01 is a private apartment interior renovation project that was carried out in the heart of Amsterdam for a passionate art collector.

The gallery-like apartment is organised on two levels: a bel etage (a spacious living and dining room and a large kitchen) and a more private sous terrain level housing two bedrooms, three bathrooms, a studio and a service room.
title: Loft 01
External Team:
Advisors
Wilfried Kramb (Ag Licht)
concepts:
Interior Concept
In order to enable the best space for the display of a spectacular art collection, UNStudio’s interior concept design focuses on maximising the wall surface, adding different display modules and optimising viewpoints. The design curates moments of everyday life defined as Living, Relaxing, Dining, Cooking and Connecting to shape bespoke fixed furniture and architectural elements that divide the space in an organic yet slightly eccentric fashion.

The most central of these elements is the semicircular and unapologetically pink staircase that leads to the sous terrain. This stair features a tall, dynamic and gate-like handrail that creates a subtle moiré effect as you move around it. Like a contemporary sculpture, this stair gently screens-off the living room from the entrance, while allowing daylight into to the darkest part of the apartment.

Art on display
Alongside the pink stair, the apartment configures other notably sculpted elements that are all designed by a recurrent composition of straight lines and arches; the bookshelf in oak wood veneered and bronzed steel, the fireplace art niche that is designed to display large canvases and sculptures and a suspended arch partition wall to the kitchen.

All of these interventions are designed to form a background that enables the client’s art collection to be displayed at its best.

description: UNStudio’s approach for the Marina Residential Tower in the Ellinikon masterplan aims to create a human-centric journey that redefines luxury and emphasises a connection to culture, nature, and community that shapes the future Athens.
title: Marina Residential Tower
External Team:
Advisors
Key Local Architect, Local Cost Consultant, Waste Management: Betaplan
Structural, Façade, Acoustic and Wind Engineering: Thornton Tomasetti 
MEP and Structural Engineering, Fire Life Safety, Vertical Transportation, Sustainability, Building Physics: Atelier Ten
Civil and Geotechnical Engineer: Langan
Landscape: Grant Associates
Local Structural Engineering: Penelis
Local MEP and Structural Engineering, Fire Life Safety, Vertical Transportation: TETRAS

Visualisations
Plomp
UNStudio
concepts:
Crafting a centerpiece
The Marina Residential Tower finds its form through a precise focus on details. It is conceived as a centerpiece that performs as one integrated system and is crafted to reflect the sun, cast graded shadows and changing light throughout the day. The façade is carved out of the silhouette of the tower and works as an integral part of the structural system. The sculpted building is composed of three main elements: the horizontal balcony planes, the curved walls and the clear enclosure.

The balcony design becomes the main identifying aspect of the project, accentuating the voluminous appearance of the building through an interplay between light and shadow. The tower plan is configured in an octagonal symmetrical shape, which assists in reducing exposure to predominant winds. The facade design introduces two contrasting materials; an alternating rhythm of solid curved walls followed by straight glass walls, as well as undulating balconies with a system of wall rotations on every floor that contributes to the dynamic impression of its appearance.

Constructing as a craftsman
The Marina Tower is conceived through a contemporary (re)interpretation of local craftsmanship. UNStudio used parametric digital tools to compose and sculpt the building. The selection of warm and earthy materials for the proposal highlights UNStudio’s tactile approach to the senses, diffuses the Attica light and brings a human scale to the space.

The slender podium sits inside a lush Mediterranean landscape and allows the tower to softly land on the ground. It is the nodal point where the welcoming areas and the social spaces for the tenants are located.

The landscape concept ‘Living in a Garden’ aims to deliver a real sense of place and a memorable experience through the utilisation of textures, materiality, colours and aromas. As such, the building creates distinctive gardens each with a unique theme; from subtropical gardens suited to the Mediterranean climate to dry gardens reminiscent of a forest.
Programme: High End Residential, Spa, Gym, indoor and outdoor pool

description:
Cologne-based project developer PANDION held an International Architectural Competition for a new mixed-use high-rise building in Düsseldorf. The design by UNStudio and OKRA Landscape Architects was chosen by the jury as the winning design by majority vote.

The Belsenpark tower, which will stand on the perimeter of the masterplan, is designed and positioned to fit the grain of the surrounding developments, in addition to connecting nearby communities.

The building's articulation is designed to fit within its surrounding context while expressing the different scales and the liveliness of its different uses from a varied and porous programme in the ground floor zone to offices on the lower levels and a rich mix of apartment types above.
title: Belsenpark
External Team:
Renderings
Flying Architecture
concepts:
The very varied apartment mix, with the addition of the cost-controlled housing, will not only enable the social integration of different demographics, it will also provide much needed housing as the city continues to densify.
Ben van Berkel, UNStudio's Founder and Principal Architect

Sound insulation
One side of the Belsenpark tower faces a busy elevated road junction. Despite being a source of high level noise pollution, all of the apartments in the tower have an outdoor area. The apartments on the side facing the street have loggias which are enclosed by sound-reducing baffle panes. The surrounding noise is further reduced both by a ventilation gap in the baffle pane and by sound-absorbing wooden.

The geometric alignment of the deep soffits in the facade elements also offer a high level of soundproofing and passive sun protection, while maximising the view of the Rhine floodplains.

Due to the comparatively low noise levels on the side facing the park, open balconies with all-glass balustrades provide unobstructed views.

Landscape planning
Belsenpark is strategically located in one of Dusseldorf’s east-west green corridors. The location of the project therefore forms a critical green link within this network, supporting new bio-diversity on a larger scale, while physically connecting various smaller green facilities at a neighborhood level.

The geometric patterns of the building facades are reflected in the landscape plan, creating seating niches along the main development and emphasising the entrances. At the intersection of the two cycle and pedestrian paths, a water feature creates an attractive place to enjoy the sun, while supporting a sustainable approach to water management.

Additionally, the integrated rainwater approach combines green components with sustainable water management tools to create a green-blue system that can buffer rainwater.

Rainwater is captured on the green roofs via a water retention layer, while the overflow is directed to the planting in the pocket park. This location can also be used as a detention basin during extreme flooding, providing a strategy for a circular water system

Sustainability
Particular attention is paid to sustainability in the proposal for this mixed-use design. In addition to using prefabricated components in construction and taking a modular approach to the supporting structure, facade and building services, the aim is to significantly reduce CO2 emissions during operations.

Modular planning simplifies the process, while focus is placed on resourcing when choosing the construction approach and materials for the design.
Programme: Office (Co-Working), Residential (Condominiums and subsidized housing), public functions as shops, cafes and health, parking

description: The new Marina Galleria, which makes up part of The Ellinikon masterplan, captures the essence of Athens’ natural environment, rich heritage and cultural allure as well as a sense of community, timelessness and the celebration of diversity.
title: Marina Galleria
External Team:
Advisors
Key Local Architect, Local Cost Consultant, Waste Management: Betaplan
Structural, Façade, Acoustic and Wind Engineering: Thornton Tomasetti
MEP and Structural Engineering, Fire Life Safety, Vertical Transportation, Sustainability, Building Physics: Atelier Ten 
Civil and Geotechnical Engineer: Langan
Landscape: Grant Associates
Way finding and Signage: Endpoint
Retail consultant: Seventh Wave
Local Structural Engineering: Penelis
Local MEP and Structural Engineering, Fire Life Safety, Vertical Transportation: TETRAS
Local Traffic Engineering: NAMA
Visualisations:

NORVISKA
Grant Associates (Landscape)
UNStudio
concepts:
Journey for all
UNStudio’s human-centric design approach fosters a seamless journey for all; creating an experience that is comfortable, safe and sociable that makes use of physical parameters, including daylight, views and sightlines for orientation. The design additionally uses technology to facilitate various transitions and transactions within the community.

The Marina Galleria project is organised along the axis of the Ellinikon Marina masterplan. Two public plazas are anchored at each end of the site, demarking the arrival points to the Galleria and the Promenade. Galleria is centrally placed along the coastline, taking maximum advantage of the sea front and the dynamism created between the two plazas.

Canopy
It is composed of a state-of-the-art lightweight canopy and two horizontal bars that house commercial units, most of which are retail shops and restaurants. The canopy provides overhead covering and weather control, while allowing visitors to enjoy the Mediterranean climate.

Sheltered under the canopy, a pedestrian galleria defines the main shopping path, which also opens up to the seaside promenade. Here, UNStudio envisions a vivid leisure and dining scene for users to enjoy the marina views, which are also framed by the Galleria. An inner path experience is organised around the Marina Gardens; four lush areas each with a distinct character create small escapes into different realms.
Programme: Retail, F&B, Fitness & Wellness, Cultural, Entertainment

description:
UNStudio’s proposal envisions an active, diverse and lively urban centre for the new Ellinikon Quarters. This area not only introduces the Ellinikon masterplan as an Entrance District, it works as a nodal point for the wider area. The impact of this node extends beyond the boundaries of the masterplan, towards the adjacent municipalities and the city of Athens, fostering the idea of a ‘20-minute city’. With the aim of becoming an important community, mobility and logistical hub, this masterplan becomes a centre for new urban life in the Greek capital.

UNStudio keenly identified that an ‘anywhere culture’ emerged following the COVID-19 pandemic. For our proposal for Ellinikon Quarters, we set about planning for resilience, tailoring a new sense of seamlessness by adapting the built environment and bringing in technology to improve quality of life.

The new Ellinikon Quarters allows for hybrid services to pop-up and occupy the mall, bringing forth a variety of experiences for visitors to the shopping district. Ellinikon Quarters has the capacity to pioneer as a service and logistical hub, becoming an important player for the entire area by capitalising on its size and infrastructural power. Aspiring to a car-free future, the strategic position of the project means that Ellinikon Quarters can become a significant mobility hub for the area. It can offer the possibility to transition from one transport modality to the other, from the metro to tram to micro-mobility modalities such as shared bicycles, Ebikes, electric scooters, and whatever the future may bring.
title: Vouliagmenis Mall and Tower - Ellinikon Quarters
External Team:
Visualisations:
Pyxid
UNStudio
concepts:
Community, Innovation, Nature and Economics
The Ellinikon Quarters aim to become a significant community driver, catering to this budding neighbourhood by providing health and well-being services, activities and learning opportunities, alongside places to socialise.

Establishing partnerships with the adjacent Municipalities, knowledge, culture and science institutions, event organisers and well-being organisations can strengthen community participation and engage users on daily basis.

With this ambition in mind, UNStudio’s vision for the new Ellinikon Quarters adheres to four key urban pillars that would transform and shape the whole area into a resilient environment: Community, Innovation, Nature and Economics. Community refers to our placemaking goal where users interact and have interconnected experiences daily. Innovation sees the introduction of creative entrepreneurship, making room for culture, arts and new industries on the site. With a range of active, learning and productive experiences, the pillar of Nature sets out to bring users closer to the environment. The pillar of Economics refers to an investment in adaptability and flexibility in order to meet the needs of the next generation.

How it all comes together
The new Ellinikon Quarters come together through a careful curation of diverse experiences, all with the shared goal of ensuring a highly visited, active and diverse centre that is safe and comfortable for all. Arriving at HQ, visitors immediately enter welcome plazas, where they are immersed into the surrounding ambience, including pop-up events or artist-brand curated events.

Each of the four plazas differently addresses its surroundings. As such, the Metro Plaza across from Leoforos Vouliagmenis acts as an entrance to the project and becomes the perfect place for a pop-up crafts and food market to attract curious passersby.

Additionally, the Tram Plaza, in a more surrounded setting, caters to events where people informally flow along the amphitheatric steps. Through the curation of free and commercial events, a diverse audience can be attracted to the site.
Promenade
The main connector throughout the project is the promenade that orchestrates the users’ experience of the space. The promenade facilitates orientation and operates as the primary distributor throughout the site, connecting the Elliniko Metro with the pedestrian axis of the masterplan. It is anchored by popular stores and large units, as well as by the food hall, which operates across the Tram Plaza’s event space.
Quarters
UNStudio’s proposal intends to create a lively, active and diverse centre for Athens, as well a scalable prototype development for retail. Organised in Quarters, the development setting synthesises the following distinct identities:
HQ1 re-imagines the way we live and work, towards a balanced well-being,
HQ2 re-thinks the way we shop within a lively neighborhood environment,
HQ3 re-defines the way we entertain, towards a resilient approach to leisure,
HQ+ re-connects the community and becomes the physical and digital platform that binds everything together.
Courtyards
Along the promenade, users can explore two main courtyards, the HQ’s ‘hidden highlights’. To the right of the promenade, going towards the Saronic Gulf, visitors find the Well-being Courtyard, which can be used for yoga sessions, health-focused eateries and related events. Further down the promenade and to the left, the passerby can meander through the Leisure Courtyard with its outdoor eating, performance and event space.
Programme: Mixed Use, Retail, F&B, Leisure, Culture and Entertainment, Office & Hotel

description:
The South Korean music scene, otherwise known as K-Pop, is currently making huge strides in the global music industry. Popular with fans from Asia to the Americas, South Korean bands are currently topping the charts and selling-out stadiums. With its fingers on the cultural pulse and a social-media-savvy fandom, K-pop is currently taking the world by storm.

In 2017, UNStudio was invited by YG Entertainment, the lead producers of K-Pop, to design their brand new headquarter building in Seoul. Since the building’s completion, it has become a pilgrimage for fans hoping to catch a glimpse of their idols.

YG Entertainment’s business and the music industry as a whole inspired UNStudio’s design for this new headquarter building, which houses office spaces, meeting rooms and recording studios. Strategically organised, these spaces take full advantage of the location and to provide YG Entertainment’s employees with the most uplifting and inspiring work environment possible.
title: Headquarters YG Entertainment
External Team:
Advisors
Gansam Architects & Partners Co. Ltd
Interior design (+ construction drawings public spaces): EOMJI HOUSE
Interior coordination : STUDIO YUUL
Lighting design: a•g Licht

Photography
©Rohspace
concepts:
Bridging two different worlds
The new HQ is located on a site that borders two very different worlds. With low-density housing areas to one side and a dense network of highways and bridges to the other while also overlooking a large green park, this positioning informs UNStudio’s entire design. From the building’s orientation to the internal organization, it serves to  open up views towards the river from the interior workplaces.

Interior design
The interior of the new HQ takes an opposite approach to the ‘black in black’ concept of the well-known pre-existing YG  building. Instead, the new building introduces brightly lit space with a range of white tones and geometric lines.

The exterior duality of the building’s surroundings are reflected in the interior organisation through an interlocking sectional concept for the functions. This logic, combined with visual coherence in materials and geometry, creates a unique interior experience that is visually linked to the exterior street level, while the roof floods the central atrium space with daylight.

The interior facade of the atrium is punctuated by exposed capsule-like meeting rooms that can serve as either ‘working zones’ or ‘resting zones’. These capsules further enable visual interaction throughout the atrium and towards the office floors. On ground level, the atrium space hosts a hidden garden and functions as a ‘living room’ to welcome visitors.

Urban Speaker
The protective shell of the building manifests as a new ‘urban speaker’. It is designed to be more reminiscent of a product than a building; one in which every design feature has a performative function.

Fully glazed areas are located towards the park and the central zone on this side of the building is equipped with balconies. These enable outside spaces for the users during work-breaks, while also providing sun shading for the levels below. BIPV solar cells are also integrated in the south-facing facade and on the roof.

Semi-glazed zones are allocated in the transition towards the fully opaque facade. In some of these solid areas, especially those located towards the housing area, dynamic lines are used to highlight certain zones, while a perforation pattern and alternation of aluminium panels and glass provide a glimpse of the functions and activities inside the building.

During the day, the ‘urban speaker’ is designed to provide the best possible working environment for its employees from the inside out, whilst at night this workplace begins to glow and become an identifiable part of the city’s skyline.

description:
UNStudio has recently completed the Shanghai Jiuguang Center, which was designed in collaboration with Nihon Sekkei. The design for this brand new retail destination, which sits in the middle of a bustling Shanghai neighbourhood merges an advanced commercial ecosystem with a human-centric, customer-friendly destination.

Collaboration was key for the creation of a symbiotic relationship between the commercial aspirations and the architectural interventions. While Nihon Sekkei were asked to develop the outer shell of the retail centre, we were tasked with fleshing out the mall as a placemaking destination for customers and the larger community.

Looking at the numerous ways users could engage with the various spaces and creating curated shopping experiences for different users informed the design of the building. This resulted in creating a synergy between the architectural and interior design, the building scale and the human scale, the geometry and materials and the inside-outside relationship.
title: Shanghai Jiuguang Center
UNStudio Team: Sontaya Bluangtook and Daniele de Benedictis
concepts:
Shopping malls are the public spaces of Chinese cities. These retail complexes are not simply places to shop, they are all-in-one destinations for outings and social gatherings. They are also places where culture and commerce merge and where architecture can express this expansive condition.
Ben van Berkel, UNStudio's Founder and Principal Architect

Curated shopping experience
The strong relationship between the exterior and interior continues in the organisation of three internal voids which are located on the perimeter of the courtyard. Each one has its own distinct identity and materialisation, based on three different themes that vertically link the shopping experience and help to orientate customers.

The urban playground, with its bright a colorful material scheme, expresses the bustle of the city outside. The materialisation of the urban oasis sets out to re-connect with nature, using warm colour tones and brass articulations throughout. The urban catwalk describes a nighttime atmosphere that is reflected in the dark, glossy materials used.

The three voids anchor the public circulation areas and create a vertical space across the different retail levels. They further supply the circulation spaces with daylight, while providing glimpses to the courtyard outside.

On every floor, a continuous retail boulevard provides access to all shops and is connected to a series of attraction points.

This retail boulevard, along with the three themed voids, form an interior public space that creates a constant flow of people, which adds to the overall orientation and curated experience of the building.
Programme: Courtyard Facade, Retail Interior, Office Interior, Courtyard Landscape

description:
The overall vision in the conceptual design for the Eastland Masterplan is to establish Ringwood as the primary mixed-use hub in Melbourne’s outer east, boasting a vibrant and contemporary hilltop town centre with integrated and sustainable retail, commercial, employment, leisure, civic and residential activities in a natural landscape setting, all connected through an advanced road and rail network.

The formation of a direct physical and visual connector between nodes to either side of the Maroondah Highway and Ringwood Street is the primary objective of the masterplan and a key step in linking disparate parts of the site.
title: Eastland Melbourne Masterplan
UNStudio Team: Wouter de Jonge and Kristoph Nowak
External Team:
Advisors
Seventh Wave London (Retail consultant)

Visualisations
Methanoia and UNStudio
concepts:
Conceptual approach
In UNStudio's conceptual design, attractive and inviting public open spaces in the heart of the town's centre underscore the vision for the Eastland Melbourne Masterplan in Ringwood. The proposed network of public spaces, located to either side of the Maroondah Highway and Ringwood Street, are expected to serve as the neighbourhood's primary public places, with the capacity to connect to Clocktower Park and a new urban space fronting Ringwood Street close to Ringwood Market.

Together, these five discreet public spaces form a legible and exposed public domain ‘loop’. As part of the masterplan's retail core, there is potential to redevelop Ringwood Market into a connected mixed-use complex, with ground-level retail and integrated upper-level commercial, business or institutional typologies. Residential uses may also be viable in this location.

Public experience
Ringwood is a suburban centre within a bushland setting. The progressive erosion of this neighbourhood's natural landscape as a result of infrastructure work is the primary incentive to ‘re-green’ the masterplan site with a native landscape in order to highlight the distinction between the ‘urban’ hub and the ‘suburban’ surroundings.
The proposed landscape would build upon the existing landscape attributes of Ringwood Lake, Greenwood Park, the Mullum Mullum Creek and freeway reservations. It would also extend a connected web of public open space and native vegetation that would completely embrace the Eastland Melbourne redevelopment.
Programme: Mixed-Use, Office, Retail, Hotel, Market and Parking

description:
Our proposal for 5YN3RGY Media Harbour in Dusseldorf is designed as a sustainable and healthy building that integrates and responds to both the environment and its urban context. The building makes full use of the location to create an attractive urban space for its users and neighbours alike.

Our responsive architectural approach is based on the creation of an integral biosphere that improves both the inner and outer air quality, creating a symbiotic relationship between outside and inside. The new biosphere is located in a natural air corridor which serves fresh air to Dusseldorf and as such, not only improves air quality in the building, but also purifies and provides cleaner air to the surrounding developments. This results in a healthy, attractive and safe urban outdoor space brought about by integrated biophilic properties.
title: 5YN3RGY Media Harbour
External Team: Advisors:
