description: The main building volume in UNStudio’s proposal for the Shenzhen Maritime Museum appears to float above a large water landscape. The surrounding wetland and coastal parks are pulled under the building to create an interior world of water and caves, inspired by the rich topography of the seabed and the currents of the oceans. The clear-cut roofline of the museum presents a distinct contrast with the surrounding hills of Shenzhen Bay.
title: Shenzhen Maritime Museum
External Team:
Advisors
Exhibition & Experience Designer: Kvorning Design, Denmark
LDI: Architectural Design and Research Institute for Guangdong Province, China
Visualisations: Atchain, China
concepts:
Architectural Build-up
The museum volume is raised above the natural wet landscape for which it is developed, establishing a strong contrast between the landscape underneath and the floating volume. The in-between space becomes a cultural playground - the so-called 3rd space. The exhibition areas are organised in the upper volume around four thematic vortexes. The two main vortexes provide different flexible connections between the exhibition floors. The landscaped roof integrates the museum with its surroundings, providing a breakout space for visitors after exploring the exhibition areas, while its playfulness provides the perfect platform from which to enjoy the views of the natural landscape of the bay and nearby hills.

The Exhibition Space
Based on the ocean’s currents the exhibition flow is designed to be experienced as a slow journey of discovery. The main stream brings you on a long journey through the different permanent collections, from the origins of the oceans to the most modern maritime technologies. At the same time multiple possibilities for alternative routes allow for a tailor-made visitor experience varying in speed and duration.

The exhibition spaces are designed to create rich moments and immersive experiences, making it possible to observe different exhibits from multiple viewpoints from different floors, thereby discovering familiar objects from unconventional perspectives.

Access and Logistics
The pedestrian connection with the surrounding landscape is emphasized, keeping the north and east sides of the plot clean of any drop off points or logistics. The main drop-off is located to the west, while the grand access is located on the north-west corner, gathering both people from the drop off and from the parks. A secondary entrance is foreseen in the south-west corner, serving people coming from the Transport hub. The south facade is dedicated to serving all the logistics with the loading bay, bus parking and parking entrance. The employee and researchers entrance is placed on the south-east corner.

Circulation and Programme Build-up
The circulation to and through the museum is a carefully curated journey that offers different choices of experience. Visitors will first submerge and move under water where they will experience the light softly filtering though the water layer. They will then emerge next to a 30 metre tall waterfall, in the centre of this underworld landscape. As they climb and explore the landscape around them, they arrive at the 3rd space: a very public and transparent elevated lobby. In this large lobby they are immersed into the depths of the sea, and through an almost ritual ascension on the main ramp, are then pushed to the surface of the water. In this vertical movement, the visitor is exposed to different exhibits, atmospheres, perspectives of the space and visual connections to the other clusters of the permanent exhibitions, that together create a rich, flexible and interconnected space.

The exhibition programme is designed to be experienced in a fluid way. The different halls and routes expand and cross each other around four main circular areas, offering multiple routes and different ways to experience the collection. Each of these circular areas has a unique character and function. The central area consists of a large ramp around a void that connects all the exhibition floors in a continuous experience. The remaining three are the centres around which the three permanent exhibitions are organised, as they spill into each other and create memorable experiences both as a network of spaces and by themselves.

The Themed exhibition about the Great Bay Area is situated on the rooftop, establishing a direct visual connection between the exhibits and the Bay Area. Through a series of large windows and terraces the explorer can finally rest and take in the beautiful natural surroundings.

The overwater area acts as an extension to the publicly accessible 3rd Space. It is an open and flexible event space catering to both visitors and locals, and is placed on top of a landmark underwater restaurant.

Sustainability
The proposal for the building aims to be a landmark in sustainability. Good water practice regarding reduced consumption, closed loop recycling and cleanliness are particularly important considering the ambition of the building to be a national education centre about the sea, and the relation of the museum with the surrounding wetlands. The waterfall and water layer of the 3rd space help cool down the warm air and create a yearlong comfortable microclimate. Grey waters are cleaned in natural biological filters in the wetland areas, before being returned to nature or being used for irrigation of the surrounding parks.

Craftsmanship
The envelope of the building is inspired by the local traditional ceramic roof tiles. Local artisans and materials would be employed in developing a contemporary interpretation of the traditional tiles. These tiles would form a breathable protective skin with differing degrees of transparency. Glass transparent tiles are interlocked to enable more open interior spaces in strategic areas. This creates a continuous envelope that is perceived differently from different viewpoints and at different times of the day, sometimes being fully closed and sometimes subtly revealing part of the interior.

The underside of the upper volume has a characteristic soft shape that relates to the landscape below. Inspired by shipbuilding, the soffit consists of high glossy hardwood planks that create ever changing water reflections from below.
Client: Planning and Natural Resources Bureau of Shenzhen Municipality

description:
For the CLEAR consortium, UNStudio created a toolkit for the design of a ‘street of the future’. Streets are the conduit of movement in cities, and history has shown that they change their character, function and use over years as they adapt to changes in mobility.

Today we live in a time of rapid changes in the field of technology. Now is the time to prepare our streets for new types of mobility and uses, and to enable people and nature to reclaim our city streets.

UNStudio’s proposal maps current changes in urban mobility and proposes a paradigm shift in relation to the parameters and design of streets of the future.

Our prototype look at Distelweg (Distel-way), a primary street in the north of Amsterdam, connecting a new ferry terminal and the rest of the ‘Noord’ area. It is currently a logistics street, serving industrial estates, but in the near future, it will become a major street for new residents and shops.

Through a collaboration with de Alliantie, a social-housing corporation with a new residential development on Distelweg, the CLEAR Amsterdam team was able to acquire insights into the residents’ aspirations for the streets. The following sections map the urban systems that the street is part of, and lay the ground for the a vision for the Distelweg in the future, acting as a prototype for a new approach to street design in relation to changing mobility needs.
title: Distelweg 'Street of the Future'
UNStudio Team: Ben van Berkel and Dana Behrman
keywords: Street of the Future Design Toolkit
concepts:
Innovation System Design
Designing the street of the future requires a clear approach to innovation. Innovation however, moves in various stages and at different speeds.

In order to create a flexible framework, we started by defining the pillars of change that the streets of the future should be designed by. We considered time as a design factor that allows for gradual transition from analogue to digital street components. Lastly, we imagined how nature and new materials would transform the appearance of streets as we know them, and turn them into places of social interaction and experience.

Street design is akin to system design – it requires key components that can interact with one another, and together create a functioning and unique organisation of materials, processes, and, in our case, space. The key components focus on our sustainable, social and resilient promise to our communities and to our planet.

Street of the Future Design Toolkit
We believe that only if we provide a healthy environment for people and nature, create socially and physically safe spaces, and invite new technology in relation to mobility into our streets, can we create an adaptable framework where the community is invited to design its own place and embed its own sense of identity.

Healthy Environment
A healthy environment is an essential part of any future street design and can manifest itself in tech installations, a generous amount of green space, electric vehicle parking spaces with charging stations, air purification filters, and regulated traffic, in combination with a reduced amount of car lanes.

Future-proof Mobility
Streets should be designed in such a way that they can adapt and re-adapt to accommodate the changing needs of users as technologies evolve. This may include the widening of bikes lanes, reducing the width of car lanes in order to accommodate self-driving vehicles and the widening of sidewalks and green space.

Social & Physical Safety
Social and physical safety can be achieved through physical landscape design elements in the streetscape, good visibility, commercial facilities on the ground level and street furniture. In order to enforce speed control proper signage and changing of the width of roads must be introduced.

Adaptability
Designing a street is not a short-term process. Streets continue to evolve as the needs of their users change. Streets should be able to adapt to changing mobility innovations, a growing need for greenery and changing commercial facilities.

Our design scenarios are based on millstones in technological development:

2020 – the current state of the street

2022 – Temporary transition that allows for an immediate upgrade of environmental and safety conditions of the site. Reduced speed and temporary/movable planters will indicate priority to pedestrians.

2030 – Enhancing the street with permanent landscape elements and additional public use. Shared surface and re-deign of the road slows traffic and allows for children and families to use the road as an extension of the public space.

2040 – Private mobility is replaced by shared autonomous pods that responds to pedestrian movement. Interactive technology is embedded in the street surface, while new building technology is introduce into the urban scape.

Distelweg in the future is a lively, safe, inclusive space for people and for nature.

description:
Following our successful collaboration with China’s leading mobile phone brand OPPO for its Guangzhou Super Flagship Store, UNStudio was also invited to design their new OPPO store in Beijing. The client wanted the same design DNA to be carried over to the Beijing store, creating a cohesive identity.

As with the Guangzhou store, the ambition of the design was to express ‘Beauty through Technology’. In Beijing, the concept of the ‘Urban Park’ remains the key driver for the design, while a sculptured staircase provides a distinctive feature within the store.

The Beijing store is located on the very prominent Wang Fu Jing Avenue, with a total of 428 m2 spread over two floors.
title: OPPO Store, Beijing
External Team:
Advisors
Local Design Institute: DOP Design
Installation & Exhibition: Leaping Creative
Lighting: Brandston Partnership inc. (BPI)

Photography
© Chenming and OPPO
concepts:
The Interior
The standout feature of the Beijing store is a sculptural stairway, which links the two floors and becomes part of the customer journey by enticing visitors to the upper level.

On the shop floor, a long, self-supporting, monolithic table serves as a display for the various smart devices.

To counteract the relatively narrow dimensions of the store, and to increase visibility, anodised aluminum panels, glass and mirror panels are used to create reflection and the illusion of depth in the space. To maintain the brand consistency, Terrazzo flooring and the backlit ceiling are carried through from the design of the flagship store in Guangzhou.

description:
In recent years, OPPO - one of China’s leading mobile phone brands and the world’s leading smart device manufacturer and innovator – has been upgrading and strengthening the communication of its brand values at a fast pace. Following the development of their Shanghai and Shenzhen super flagship stores, OPPO set their sights on communicating their forward-thinking brand values in the Chinese city of Guangzhou. As a result, in 2019, UNStudio was appointed as the design architect for the OPPO Guangzhou Super Flagship Store. UNStudio was asked to redesign the 606 m2 customer experience interior space, alongside a completely new 300 m2 facade.

Designing a technology flagship store requires a very specific approach, as the design has to reflect the philosophy of the brand, while remaining appropriate to the company’s existing design aesthetic and ethos. In this instance, it was therefore essential to create a total brand experience for the customers that was highly tailored to OPPO. The aim was to create a design that would become an integral and recognisable part of OPPO’s overall branding and a valued experience that OPPO’s customers will want to engage with and return to.

For OPPO customers, existing and new, the newly designed Guangzhou Super Flagship Store provides a venue where they can familiarise themselves with - and get excited about – OPPO’s products. For OPPO as a brand, the store represents the ‘face’ of the company in Guangzhou; a visual brand identity that goes beyond the products and a mere physical point of contact with their customer base.

UNStudio was also invited to carry over the same design DNA to the prominent new Wangfujing Avenue OPPO store in Beijing.
title: OPPO Super Flagship Store, Guangzhou
External Team:
Advisors
Local Design Institute: DOP Design
Installation & Exhibition: Leaping Creative
Lighting: brandston partnership inc.(BPI)

Photography
© CreatAR Images
© Yiyi and OPPO
concepts:
Design Concept - Urban Park
Guangzhou is a wonderful mix of a historical and a modern, forward-looking city. The challenge of designing an OPPO store within this city is to develop a contextual reaction and strategy that respects the qualities of the city, while also representing OPPO’s brand values. With the ambition to create a gathering space that blurs the boundaries between public space and commerce for OPPO’s new and existing customers, UNStudio introduced an ‘Uban Park’ concept. This concept creates an inclusive environment that meets the behavioral needs of the various people who visit the store. The interior is designed as a ‘borderless’ interactive environment, where meandering routes surround a central resting point, thereby creating different rhythms of motion and allowing customers to browse, take their time, pause and try out the products within the store.

The Facade – the Modular Tube
The design for the Guangzhou OPPO flagship store is approached through a keen focus on craftsmanship, alongside material choices that add a contemporary twist to the vernacular architecture of the city.

A streetside facade design was required that would provide the store with a strong and recognisable visual identity. As a result, a repeated tube form was chosen, inspired by bamboo - an important source of food, clothing, housing, and transportation for people in Guangzhou in ancient times - as the main modular element used in the facade. This metallic tube is also an interpretation of the ‘O’ in OPPO, when it is transformed from 2D into 3D. This dimensional transformation results in a cylindrical tube, into which a cut is added in order to obtain a truncated cylinder. This cylindrical form becomes the main modular element and is repeated throughout the facade, creating a reference to both the brand and to technology.

For the overall composition of the facade elements, multiple geometric strategies were studied. Following the exploration of different volumetric options, a large, sweeping folding gesture was chosen which echoes the corner curve of the OPPO brand logo, while guiding visitors towards the entrance to the store.

Lighting effects are then added to create an overall effect of dynamism and vibrancy. This results in an optical effect of rhythmic motion across the facade, representing the New OPPO Culture, new technologies and the pulse of OPPO as a company experiencing continuous growth.

At the indoor entrance, located within the mall, a ‘grey space’ space is created between the interior and the atrium. Here the materials used in the interiors and large LED screens extend from inside the store out into the atrium, minimising the store’s boundary.

The Interior – Fluid, Continuous Geometry
Achieving a fluid space in a flowing, uninterrupted yet dynamic way - where an intuitive sequence of different areas enables customers to experience and interact with the products - was one of the key aims of the interior design.

The interior space is defined by two main areas: PULSE and EVOLUTION. In the PULSE area the main phone displays act as a strong focal point, while the EVOLUTION area, in contrast, enables different experiences and accommodates a café and social zones. Throughout the store charging seats are installed around translucent pillars. Referencing social clusters around trees in a park, these seating elements provide comfortable areas for customers to relax and socialise. The store also provides customers with a playful experience zone, where they are also encouraged to discover the features of the phone’s cameras by taking photos and selfies.

Natural colours and fluid forms are applied in the interior. Anodized aluminum plate with a customised surface treatment is used alongside micro and translucent textured partitions, creating the perception of subtly layered changes of depth throughout the interior. Green granite terrazzo flooring is used to create meandering paths through the store, while integrated ‘pathways’ of lighting in the ceiling mimic this fluid flow and frame the different areas and displays from above. These pathways in the floor and ceiling further serve to guide visitors intuitively along various routes as they wander through and around the space.
Programme: Retail Store, facade and interior renovation design

description:
UNStudio’s proposal for the Future ShanShui City brings the local cultural tradition of Lishui to the 21st century through the translation of traditional formal structures into a future that provides comfort, forms the basis of a close community and instills a sense of safety.

The design was inspired by the vernacular courtyard-house style, a typology that appears also in local ShanShui paintings. This approach meant designing an urban development that live in harmony with its surroundings, ensuring minimal and considered intervention in the landscape.
title: Future ShanShui City
External Team:
Advisors
Landscape and ecology: GrossMax
Mobility: Systematica
User experience technology: UNSense
Visuals: Plomp
concepts:
Urban Rooms Concept
To integrate old and new into the city plan, we devised an Urban Rooms concept for Lishui. To do this, we looked to the concept of the ancient courtyard house and brought it into the modern day.

Traditionally, these ancient houses with interior courtyards stood solitarily to protect the inhabitants from outside threats. But in our design for the new Lishui Urban Rooms, we linked them by paths, roads, the landscape and the river, turning the structures into a multi-nodal network of urban settlements.

The 'rooms' have a defined perimeter, created by the alignment of buildings or trees, and the inner area can be filled with either low-density housing or gardens. This approach delivered an innovative urban plan that ensured a future-proof model that contrasts with urban sprawl.

Integrated into the landscape, supported by smart and green mobility and connected via a digital network, these Urban Rooms offer a safe and productive space for a mixed community to grow and prosper.

Providing Room for the River
The key Landscape Development proposals are based on:

- Providing ‘Room for the River’ by ensuring a wider floodplain in order to prevent urban flooding, improving water quality and bio-diversity, and providing a new dynamic landscape setting for urban development projects.

- Avoiding suburban sprawl; instead, concentration of urban development is expressed as ‘urban rooms’.

- The creation of a blue-green infrastructure between the urban and the rural territories, where a system of renewable energy, dynamic wetlands and productive landscapes can be developed.

This landscape vision is not only based on providing more room for the river, but also to increase agricultural productivity. The historical geography of water management in Lishui reveals a highly complex hydraulic system that has become tightly interwoven with the urban structure. This system can be utilised to structure future development.

The strategy promotes sustainable agriculture focused on horticulture, bio-fuel crops, fishponds and orchards clustered around existing villages to create a new urban/rural morphology and housing typologies.

5 New Neighbourhoods
Our proposal for the Lishui New Dwellings Masterplan is spread over five locations:

The Portal of ShanShui – the urban touch point of the site
The Ancient city Heritage - the island of possibilities
The Wind of Kuocang Mountain – a place of innovation
The Rhyme of Sidu – a unique community
Guyan Painting countryside – the spiritual heart of this project

description:
Many residential buildings in the EU urgently need to undergo energy-efficient renovations. In tandem, society is becoming increasingly aware of the negative impact our living environments can have on our planet, and us. Combined, these factors present a vast challenge: how do we improve our building stock’s performance on an EU-wide scale?

Through BIM-SPEED, we aim to address this challenge by developing a combination of methodologies and tools with one central information source at its core: the Building Information Model (BIM), a digital representation of a building. This model will be the catalyst for a smarter and more efficient deep renovation method for the residential building sector.

Run by a consortium of 24 companies from various disciplines, including architects, engineers and developers, the purpose of the BIM-SPEED project is to determine the most energy efficient alterations for buildings, with the aim to reduce their energy usage by 60%. It also aims to help reduce the renovation time by 30%.
title: BIM-Speed Platform - Simplifying Deep Renovation Projects
External Team:
Advisors
Technische Universität Berlin 
DEMO Consultants
Centre Scientifique et Technique du Bâtiment 
Fundación CARTIF
HOCHTIEF ViCon GmbH
CYPE SOFT SL
Planen-bauen 4.0
Università Politecnica delle Marche
STRESS
ARCADIS Romania
FASADA
MOSTOSTAL WARSZAWA SA
LKS INGENIERIA S.COOP
Erasmus Universiteit Rotterdam
VISESA Vivienda y Suelo de Euskadi, S.A. 
CONSEIL DES ARCHITECTES D'EUROPE
Federation of European Heating, Ventilation and Air Conditioning Associations
Fédération de l`Industrie Européenne de la Construction
EUROPEAN BUILDERS CONFEDERATION (EBC)
Metabuild
keywords: How BIM-SPEED Can Answer Growing Renovation Needs
concepts:
How BIM-SPEED Can Answer Growing Renovation Needs
Most of the existing building stock in the EU has reached the age for renovation: 90% of the was built before 1990 and 40% was built before energy-performance standards for buildings were introduced. Of this total stock, 75% is residential properties.

By adopting BIM-SPEED technology, it will be possible to store all of a building’s information in a central hub, and to use this information to digitally plan and test the performance of renovations on virtual 3D models before undertaking them on the physical structure. With this technology, everything from the placement of windows to the materials used can be tested and optimised for its performance and environmental impact in advance

Simplifying Deep Renovation Projects
BIM-SPEED focuses on users as the key success factor for BIM adoption, and develops ways for deep renovation projects to achieve EU energy efficiency targets. It provides all of the stakeholders in the housing renovation market with holistic solutions, which include an affordable cloud-based BIM platform, a set of interoperable BIM tools, validation and standardised set of procedures for implementing renovation solutions for guaranteed energy performance and inhabitants’ comfort.

BIM-SPEED solutions will be supported with evidence from 13 real demonstration cases, covering all of Europe’s climatic geo-clusters and varying BIM experience levels in different countries.

UNSx, UNStudio’s innovation thinktank and experience design unit, is responsible for the practical framework for BIM-based lighting and visual comfort assessment in renovation projects. The work package will deliver the BIM-SPEED methodology and tools for the holistic building performance assessment, dedicated to energy efficient building renovation projects, and integrated with the use of the BIM-SPEED Platform.

The deliverable proposes a standardised method for the implementation of BIM for lighting and visual comfort, and the interoperability solutions between the analytical tools and the BIM-SPEED Platform. It also includes the analysis outcomes of the selected real demonstration case in conjunction with the EU’s Work Package 8, as an input for optimal renovation solutions in WP7/T7.1.

Read more about the project: here

description:
One of the consequences of the ‘always on’ workforce is increased stress and burnout. Work-related stress is the second most frequently reported work-related health problem, and is a factor in 50-60% of all lost working days. Without prevention, it will continue to be a huge financial burden on companies while severely impacting our quality of life.

RESET™ (Responsive Emotional Transformation) aims to help tackle this issue by allowing people to take a break from everyday pressures to rebalance, refocus, and reset.

As part of our ongoing investigations into the future of learning and working, and how the built environment can be adapted to improve quality of life in years to come, we designed - in collaboration with Scape - the RESET stress reduction pods. These mobile, modular structures address the urgent need for stress relief in the workplace by empowering people to deal with stress more effectively.
title: RESET 2.0 Stress Reduction Pods
UNStudio Team: William de Boer and Filippo Lodi
External Team:
Scape
Jeff Povlo, Nicola Tordoff Söhne, Chris Malbon, Steven Smith
concepts:
Rebalance. Refocus. Reset.
RESET offers up to six different scientifically proven stress reduction methods. From intimacy to sound therapy, each modular unit provides a unique experience in a playful, interactive way.

Personalised solutions are the most effective and efficient, so RESET also learns user preferences and shares their progress. To do this, RESET provides wearable technology (brain and heart sensors) that monitor biofeedback and user activity outside the pods, while sensors integrate data to personalise user experience inside the pods. With this information, the The Reset Index™, a proprietary algorithm that combines head and heart data, can analyse the user’s psychophysiological state.

Based on how the user responds to active versus passive experiences in the pods, the algorithm determines their resilience to stress and recommends the most suitable types of stress reduction methods.

Mobile and Modular
The units are designed as objects that fit anywhere, and distorting the base geometry creates a modularity that allows for various scenarios. The units are angled at 45 and 90 degrees, which makes it easy to position them in a group; two 45-degree units form a corner of 90 degrees, and all six units can stand alone in a circle of 360 degrees, forming a full experience cluster.

The unique exterior of each unit also means the themes are distinguishable from the outside. This fully immersive experience allows employees to take a break from everyday pressures to rebalance, refocus, and reset.

A platform like RESET isn’t the only solution to managing employee stress, but using it in the workplace sends a positive signal to potential and current employees.

Have a look at the first Reset Pods here.
Programme: Pod design for stress relieving experience

description: UNStudio’s proposal for the Knowledge Mile Park Bridge proposes a much-needed, safe connection between the two sides of the campus of Amsterdam University of Applied Sciences (HvA). Located along the Wibautstraat in Amsterdam, the campus is currently separated by a busy dual carriageway that cuts straight through the faculty buildings.
title: Knowledge Mile Park Bridge
concepts:
Wooden Walkway
The Park Bridge, which will be constructed entirely from wood, is designed as an ecological, social and climate neutral structure, a place for people to come together, a space for relaxation, small events and as a living lab for students, local residents and visitors alike.

A Powerful Symbol
The plan not only has the ambition to create a safe connection for the divided campus, but also to create a powerful symbol of this link by way of an elevated footpath and park. It will form a central location on the HvA campus that is accessible to everyone and forms the crowning glory of the Knowledge Mile Park.
Client: Amsterdam University of Applied Sciences (Hogeschool van Amsterdam)

description:
The vision for this project is to create a tailored living experience, which creates not only a destination for the residents, but a vibrant, lively common ground for the neighbourhood.

The shaping of communities plays an important role, and this project aims to tackle this on three different scales: the public  (urban design), the building (architecture) and the human (interior design). For each of these three scales, UNStudio devised a strategy that both establishes unique experiences and caters to future users.
title: Vancouver Mixed-Use Tower
External Team:
Visualisations
Flying Architecture
concepts:
The Urban Scale
The site has the potential to strongly link multiple functions, thus becoming a new local centre and a multi-layered new public stepping stone within the urban fabric. The mixed-use podium, consisting of retail, F&B and start-up offices, is terraced, stepping up from the ground to the top of the podium, thus creating a new common ground. The centre of the podium consists of a green courtyard which terraces upwards and provides visibility throughout.

The Building Scale
On the building scale, the massing is designed from the inside out, similar to the human experience beginning from within. The residential towers are defined through setbacks, lookouts, and shifts in volumes that provide enhanced views, double height balconies and stepped terraces. Rotating sky gardens provide elevated amenity experiences.

The Human Scale
On the human scale, designing with the details in mind is something that has an immediate impact on end users, whose wellbeing is directly connected to designed features - from the layout design of an apartment to the selection of a sophisticated material palette. In order to boost wellbeing and public health, the goal is to create a balance across these design features, from greenery across indoor and outside spaces, to creating living areas and outdoor spaces that become an extension to apartment living, as well as creating an equilibrium between grand panoramic views and intimate community spaces.
Programme: 2 residential towers with mixed-use podium and amenities

description:
The Banpo Dong Project is located in a unique and prominent site along the Han River. Its close proximity to multiple natural reserves and parks, easy access to public transit and numerous schools in the neighbourhood, make it one of the most sought after and highly desired residential addresses within Seoul.

The complex consists of six luxury residential towers and amenities embedded into a lush green landscape. UNStudio’s vision for the project is to create a luxurious, yet future-proof environment, which focuses on building a community and facilitating a healthy and sustainable lifestyle.
title: Banpo Dong 12
External Team:
Visualisations
Flying Architect
concepts:
The Private Art Collection
The facade design draws inspiration from the idea of a “The Private Art Collection”, and aims to create tailored living experiences for each of the residents. Each tower consists of a different set of “Art Collections”, creating a hyper-personalised living experience for each of the user groups.  A diverse set of amenities create an exclusive living experience for the residents, which prioritise healthy living and community activities.

A Secret Garden
The landscape creates a secret garden for the residents, enabling them return home to a lush and natural oasis within the busy confines of the city. The path design is based on the leaf concept, branching to create primary and secondary paths. Multiple amenities are interwoven within the garden such as picnic areas, playgrounds, meditation areas, art gardens, orchard gardens and outdoor gyms. Special gardens at each of the amenity spaces are planted with the seasons in mind, blooming all year round.

description: The Banpo Dong 7 Project is a large development located off Sinbanpo-ro Road, within close proximity to the Han River and multiple parks and rivers within the area. The mixed-use project is comprised of 17 residential towers and a commercial and office complex.
title: Banpo Dong 7
External Team:
Visualisations
Flying Architecture
concepts:
A Healthy Living Environment
The key driver for the project is the creation of a healthy living environment for the diverse community, and providing spaces that promote well-being, offer accessibility to nature and that incorporate technology in such a way as to enhance privacy and security.

Designing for Residents
The facade design is based on natural rock formations found within the Korean landscape. Different families of tower typologies and facades are clustered into neighbourhoods, creating a sense of identity for the residents. Residential amenities such as sky gardens provide views onto the city and elevated community spaces for the residents.
Programme: Façade design 17 residential towers with amenities

description:
Located on one of the primary traffic corridors within the Melbourne CBS, 570 Little Bourke Street is a mixed-use development that will also celebrate the historical “pub culture” of this Australian city by retaining and re-using the existing Great Western Hotel that sits at its base.

Covering four lots, this development boasts frontages on King Street, Little Bourke Street and Brown Alley, and will blend office and retail space - as well as food and beverage facilities - to bring new life to the area. The ground plane focuses on public space activation and placemaking, connecting three main street frontages with the public square behind the site. This notion of public space also continues vertically into the breakout-area within the workspace.
title: 570 Little Bourke Street
External Team: XO Projects: Igor Kebel, Eriko Watanabe, Shalom Chang, Bennett Wang, Stephen Hannon, Wicks Wang, Sara Tan

Advisors
Acoustic Engineer: Acoustic Logic
Building Services: WSP
Building Surveyor: Gardner Group
ESD Consultant: Ark Resources
Heritage: Bryce Raworth
Landscape Architect: Aspect Studios
Placemaking: Village Well
Quantity Surveyor Rider: Levett Bucknall
Town Planning Consultant: Urbis
Traffic Consultant: Traffix
Waste Management: Leigh Design
Wind Engineer: Windtech
concepts:
Key Location
The key characteristics of the development site include not only the King Street frontage, but the rear laneways of Brown Alley and Merrits Place, as well as the yet unnamed square between the two. The Laneways are surrounded by historical blue stone buildings and provide a calm and peaceful environment away from the activity of King Street, which sits on the fringe of the city’s legal precinct and in the evening is known as a hub of Melbourne nightlife. The proposed development will provide a food and beverage focus to the laneways, reinvigorating and activating this currently neglected space.

“The 570 Little Bourke project will unlock a piece of Melbourne for the public again with a 180 degree activated public podium that connects to the intimate hidden square via the newly activated Brown Alley. We are very proud to be able to contribute to this development and bring new life and quality to the area.”  Ben van Berkel, Founder and Principal Architect UNStudio

Urban Design Response
Our design integrates a central vertical spine facing King Street, which adds social and green spaces that work in collaboration with the outer public realm. It’s not only a physical design feature, but also promoted a functional relationship between the street and the spine. At the ground level, the spine recess invites users inside the building and provides a sheltered zone while respecting the existing heritage building. At the office levels, the spine hosts various collaboration and breakout spaces.

Differing Facade Types
The subdivision of the building into various block forms is broken down into a finer grain through a palette of facade textures. Seven facade families are designed to populate the blocks and bring a rich, tactile differentiation to the overall facade. For the tower volume on the corner of King Street and Little Bourke, we employed a simple curtain wall system combined with vertical solid elements to reduce heat load on the interior. These solid elements pick up pace along the length of King Street and Browne Alley. On the Little Bourke side, which receives less heat, we embraced maximum facade transparency to optimise the amount of daylight flooding into the office levels and the views over King Street and the city skyline.

“This development will elevate the quality and offering of our workplaces with future-proofed workplace design, superior amenity and unparalleled design excellence”. Nick Argyrou, Managing Director, Argo Group

“The power of 570 Little Bourke is a fusion of the boutique sectors, which blurs between corporate, hospitality and retail. The design combines environments that blend the best of them all“. Igor Kebel, Co-Founder and Principal Architect XO Projects

description: The Green Jade masterplan currently hosts steel industry facilities and contaminated land. The proposal turns a polluted industrial area by a process of land remediation into a model city of the future with key facilities that ensure a lively city – cultural and education institutes, office buildings, and residential units. Hangang’s Green Jade is the place to live and work in the near future that nurtures technology while honouring nature.
title: Hangang Green Jade
External Team:
Visualisations
San Lab, Beijing
Physical Models: Shanghai Wenzhu Model Design
Sustainability/circularity: Except Integrated sustainability, Utrecht
keywords: Hangang district is a place for people
concepts:
Creating a robust urban network
With a multi-modal mobility network that seamlessly connects to the existing Handan fabric, the new Hangang District pays homage to what is the most important to the future of Handan. The residents are invited to new residential neighbourhoods, which offer a variety of types of dwellings and safe outdoor spaces for all. Handan’s past history and culture is used in this new chapter of future history that is created in the Arts District.  A vibrant urban neighbourhood with indoor and outdoor spaces dedicated to cultural and artistic expressions. The district’s proximity to the Green Jade allows to directly link the site’s history. Handan’s beautiful and healthy environment is evident throughout the whole masterplan, but it is uniquely represented by the Green Village, located next to an existing traditional village of Handan, offering low density living, and promoting recreational activities, wellbeing and health. The Knowledge hub is a bustling and stimulating district filled with labs, research, education facilities, orientated towards the development technological innovations of the future.

Restoring the natural mesh
Considering the environmentally challenging times we live in, we must design not just for economic benefits of the city, but also for physical, social and mental wellbeing of its residents. Therefore, all of the diverse neighborhoods in the masterplan are joined by a mesh of unifying threads – nature. Just like urban form, Hangang’s green spaces manifest themselves in different shapes and forms. Besides traditional parks, urban gardens and pocket parks, our proposal offers productive and technological landscapes. With the new approach to landscape design we restore the nature systems that were there before, enhance the existing and introduce new eco-systems which contribute to health and productivity of Handan. In order to secure the success of future urban development, cities can no longer be seen as solely economic-profit driven spaces. They must offer qualitative natural environments that are weaved into their urban fabric in order to be considered livable, and desirable.

Hangang district is a place for people
The masterplan proposal, where technology, nature and culture are united for all to experience. By designing an environment of diversity and opportunity we encourage the local community to flourish, attract and foster new talent that contributes to the future-proofing of Handan. The vision of Hangang’s urban development will secure its legacy as part of Handan’s economic power, political center, a capital of arts and culture, while opening up new opportunities for its residents and industries.
Client: Hebei Provincial Department of Housing & Urban-Rural Development and Department of Natural Resources of Hebei Province / competition organized by UED Magazine
Programme: Mixed use – residential, office, commercial, public space – 10.5M m2

description:
The shatterproof Giro Kids Collection tableware uses bright and contrasting colours that have an instant appeal to children.

Expanding upon the primary colours usually used in children’s products, the tableware set comprises a plate, bowl and cup in shades ranging from Coral Red and Azure Blue to Nectarine Orange and Minty Green - from which children can make combinations, or claim their favourite as their own.

The gentle curves and wide edges enable easy grip, while detachable anti-slip rubber rings anchor the tableware to any surface, helping to avoid messy mealtimes. BPA-free and made from melamine and bamboo, the Giro Kids Collection tableware provides safe and highly sustainable children’s tableware for any occasion.

The set is part of the Alessi Kid's Collection, which includes a 3-piece cutlery set and the 'Doraff', designed by Ben van Berkel and the team at UNStudio.
title: Giro Kid's Collection Tableware
concepts:
I have always enjoyed the playfulness of how children perceive and explore the world around them; how the scope of their imagination allows them to think beyond rational boundaries, and how this liberation from logic enables the most creative ideas and perceptions. Trying to grasp this kind of mindset stimulates your own creativity as a designer and you have to keep it very much in mind when you design for children.

Ben van Berkel, UNStudio's founder and principal designer

description:
The Giro Kids Collection comprises a children’s cutlery set and tableware, designed for Italian design brand Alessi. The cutlery originates from our Giro cutlery collection, designed for Alessi in 2016 as part of our longstanding partnership.

The kid's cutlery allows children to mimic adults by using the same utensils as they do, while also helping them to learn how to use, hold and balance their cutlery correctly.

Made from polished steel, the twist in the handle enables grip and balance for both right and left-handed children
title: Giro Kid's Collection Cutlery
concepts:
"When you design a product for adults, you concentrate on its functionality and how to couple that with its materiality, aesthetic and spatial qualities. But something else happens when you design for children: different, more playful ideas start to rise to the surface, because you start to approach the design through the mind of a child.

Ben van Berkel, UNStudio's founder and principal architect
Programme: Giro Kid's Collection Cutlery Set, three pieces

description:
CityLife is an ambitious commercial and residential development on Milan’s historic former trade fair grounds: the Fiera Milano. The development has a strong focus on sustainability: ‘smart’ buildings with high energy performance, a car-free zone and a diversity of developed public and green spaces. It would also become the second largest green park in Milan.

The brief for the CityLife International Design Competition was to complete the development by designing the last two remaining plots, with the urban area in between. To add this last chapter to CityLife, it was essential to understand the importance of the project as an urban and real estate development. After thorough analysis, UNStudio proposed to aim for a finely crafted, high performance urban campus and create diversity in both function and architecture, as well as form a stronger transition between the existing urban fabric and the connecting neighbourhoods.

UNStudio’s concept is data-driven and based on variables that define efficiency, constructability, flexibility, sustainability and wellbeing, with an overall emphasis on craftsmanship. The design is centred around people and focusses on the comfort and wellbeing of each person who would work in, live in or simply pass by CityLife. The design offers a memorable and engaging space; a healthy recreational and working environment. The proposal encompasses physical, mental, social and environmental health. The new campus layout aims to result in a framework for the built environment and space where elements and solutions are human-centric and implement the most progressive level of engineering, innovation and sustainability.
title: CityLife, International Design Competition Parcel Re & Rd
External Team:
Advisors
Architect of Record/ Local Architect: SBGA
Environmental Design, Structural Engineering, Building Services, Façade Engineering, Acoustics Engineering Services: Arup   
Mobility: MIC – Mobility in Chain
Landscape: Green4Cities
Fire Safety: Studio Mistretta & Co
Cost Estimation: GAD
Visualisations: Studio Negativ, AAND3
concepts:
Urban Regeneration
The newly proposed buildings are predominantly different from their surroundings. A new resolution and quality is introduced in the architecture and the landscape. The aim is to attract different user types to CityLife in order to create social diversity. The target of all design decisions is to establish quality space for people to dwell and to engage with; space which will engender strong emotional attachments, which form the cornerstone of community building. Attractive and comfortable workspaces, public space and intimate green areas that people will want to return to time and time again, and a memorable hotel. The design aims to connect people and strengthen CityLife’s position as a Milan destination for visitors and locals alike. The design subtly relates to the former fairground; its aim to entertain, the playfulness of its details and Its social accessibility.

Spatial Experience
The two towers are shaped by consciously set programmatic intentions. The volumes reflect the changes in the spatial requirements of the interiors and their functions. The facade openings signal changes in function, while connecting the indoor and outdoor environments. Social spaces are clustered in the large gestures of the volumes in order to activate the buildings vertically and create space for interaction. These spaces also introduce a biophilic green environment to the interior.

The indoor environment is inspired by traditional Milanese interiors and uses only circular materials, which support the zero energy target. The interior is designed to be a responsive environment where specific elements are in dialogue with the users. For instance the lighting is controlled by occupancy, but can also be personalised it in the common spaces. The data analysis based monitoring of the spaces makes operations efficient and the user experience bespoke.

A hotel is located in the higher tower at the top of the development, thereby fully utilising the potential of the CityLife site. The design of the hotel originates from traditional Milanese courtyards. The lobby is located in a floating garden that expands through the hotel volume, floating above the entire office block and CityLife. Upon arrival, visitors find themselves in a semi-outdoor, green and lush garden. All of the hotel rooms are accessed from this space, which also offers the most spectacular views of Milan.

Future of Workspace
UNStudio’s proposal offers a flexible and efficient framework to accommodate changing future needs and a variety of potential tenants and users. The two buildings both apply a vertical social campus concept where workspace is clustered around community, thereby enhancing interaction, creativity and engagement between users. These social gathering spaces - visible in the appearance of the towers - are the heart and soul of the buildings. They are strengthened by their connection to the exterior and with green areas which further blur the boundaries of interior and exterior and increase the performance, motivation and efficiency of the users.

The workspace is designed to serve three main different types of activity, in order to guarantee flexibility of usage. Typical cccupants are freelancers, entrepreneurs, start-ups and small teams that require dynamic, versatile and varied workspaces.  A personalised environment, alongside communication suites includes both individual and group workspaces.

Formal office layouts per floor - that are supported by optimal daylight conditions - include small break-out spaces for social interaction. This layout is optimised for focused work where full concentration is required.

The collaborative office levels are designed to foster workplace communities and teamwork. Circulation and workplace zones are arranged to encourage interaction and communication. High flexibility and a diversity of spaces provide the opportunity to attract different users.

The design of creative workspace revolves around the concept of ‘encountering’. As such the CityLife workspaces are designed to inspire; to provide a catalyst for spontaneous interactions and the exchange of ideas. These offices are a combination of shared individual and teamwork spaces, which are linked visually to stimulate social activity and accelerate the generation of innovation.

A Sustainable Approach
Our vision for CityLife also included sustainable and circular design features, with the aim to make the development more green.

As part of this, we included rainwater harvesting provisions, grey water recycling facilities, urban farming areas, and solar panels on the rooves. We also applied specific orientations to the buildings to reduce solar radiation.

description:
UNStudio’s proposal for the New Port District in Turku explores how we can live with water in the 21st century. It will be an interface, where urbanity and nature meet and coexist.

Three distinct urban areas are proposed, consisting of new and existing urban anchors and highlighting the potential of maritime areas. The areas are united by a multifunctional and attractive shoreline that not only protects, but also offers diversity for both nature and people.

Like the medieval Turku Castle in the past, the new Turku Maritime District will be a catalyst for new innovations and cultural developments. Connecting the city and the sea, our proposal for a new waterfront hub consists of three main areas: ‘Port City’, with a proposal to relocate Turku Fair Centre and blue marine businesses; ‘Museum Gardens’, which combines the Castle and a new Museum, and the ‘Maritime Quarter’, with local restaurants and new types of waterfront housing.
title: Linnanniemi Waterfront Masterplan
External Team:
Advisors
Co-designers: Lunden Architecture
Landscape, engineering, mobility, sustainability: WSP
History: Panu Savolainen (University of Turku)
CGI Visuals: Plomp
keywords: A Landmark of the Finnish Archipelago
concepts:
Diverse and Active Waterfront District
Given its prime location and history, Linnanniemi has the potential to become the new centre of maritime culture, innovation and ecology. The proposed functions are based on and enhance existing valuable characteristics of the site. They also bring activities that can be enjoyed 24/7, all year round.

Port City: New home for the Turku Fair and Blue Marine Businesses
Port City is an industrial and innovative quarter dedicated to international events, marine industry, business and research. It provides a unique site for the relocated Turku Fair Centre, is connected to local and international transportation networks and surrounded by a new Hotel and Congress Centre and ferry terminal. While exhibition spaces, street food and bars take over ground floors, upper floors accommodate growing marine businesses.

Museum Gardens: All-year-round Cultural and Natural Heart
The Museum Gardens is an all-year-round cultural, recreational and biodiverse attraction that creates a unique setting for large-scale outdoor events. The concentrated green and pedestrian-oriented area brings together historic and new structures. The new Museum is an extension of the Castle and linked by pavilions and relocated storehouses. The gardens offer a lush and dynamic shorefront that showcases the biodiverse marine environment.

Maritime Quarter: Finland's New Culinary Destination
The Maritime Quarter is a new pedestrian area combining famous local cuisine and bistros with maritime history, waterfront housing and smaller cultural outdoor venues. Its sheltered shorefront between Hostel Borea and Suomen Joutsen offers a variety of water activities, such as outdoor swimming, boating and floating stages, generating a new hyggelig small-scale area that attracts both locals and tourists from Finland and abroad.

A Landmark of the Finnish Archipelago
The new Museum is strategically located at the mouth of the River Aura, welcoming all travellers to the new Maritime District and City of Turku. As part of a dynamic waterfront, the museum area transforms into an island, becoming an extension of the Finnish Archipelago when the water rises. Its iconic location offers the possibility for an exciting dialogue with the Turku Castle, which is further enhanced with vibrant green spaces and repurposed wooden houses situated between the two destinations. With simple geometries offering spectacular panoramic views, the new Museum seeks to create an elegant new landmark that complements rather than competes with the Castle’s historic architecture.

description: Located at the intersection of Akti Miaouli and Akti Posidonos in Piraeus and overlooking the Port, our proposal for the regeneration of the Piraeus Tower acquires a mixed identity within this setting. Having remained vacant over recent decades, the tower has come to be known as ‘the sleeping giant’. Therefore, our design seeks to remodel the facade in order to re-brand the image of the tower - thus attracting a new community to the heart of Piraeus – in addition to designing a sustainable building that places the health and well-being of every user at its core.
title: Piraeus Tower
concepts:
Design Approach
The goal was to create a bridge between the existing rational design approach and one that is human-centric. Alongside the international style of the original tower design by Architects Vikelas, Molfezis and Loizos, the reference to the famous grid of Hippodamus is retained.

The design of the new tower is envisaged as a vessel of life and of diverse activities, thus stepping away from the monolithic image. A series of ribbons are introduced that frame the tower closer to the urban scale, where the building becomes a series of stacked blocks with different characteristics from street to top.

The heart of the new Piraeus Tower becomes the point where the tower meets the podium, while the podium is opened up to create an interior passage, enabling daylight to guide movement. The podium terrace becomes the shared place of the new community, where they can meet, work and play.

Our proposal presents Piraeus as a place of synergies; between natural and manmade, arrival and departure, rational and organic, cityscape and seascape. Inspiration is taken from all these dualities and a façade is introduced that performs as a veil; a play between seeing through and feeling protected, harnessing the wind and reflecting the water.

Throughout the plinth and tower, the veil acts as a second skin and consists of a series of crafted and performative fins. Through an informed design process, the frequency and depth of the fins is altered to generate a ripple effect, creating the effect of a breeze across the surface, while protecting the building from site and environmental conditions. The fins respond to a set of contextual, performative and programmatic parameters, producing a different effect on each side of the building. Through the control of a set of fin variables: length, depth and coloration, the fins acoustically shield the building from interruption from the hustle and bustle of the city. In addition they block the strong summer sun while enabling a diffused light to enter the interior spaces. The irregular distribution of fins breaks down the vertical exterior surface of the Tower, thus interrupting the wind downfall and ensuring the comfort of all the surrounding public spaces.

The interior glazed skin ensures the functional requirements of the tenants, whilst remaining transparent and causing the least visual impact. An Important goal of the facade design is to allow the soft Attica sky light into the building, as well as to capture the sea breeze through air-hatches that can be manually operated by the tenants. These parameters ensure the health and productive well-being of tenants in their workspaces.

The proposed facade design approach capitalises on the flexibility of the existing Tower. Recognising the dynamic environment in which we live, with plenty of economic and social fluctuations, the resilient approach will contribute to a future-proof design for Piraeus Tower. By breaking the building into a series of blocks, its relevance to the human and urban scale is ensured. By introducing the design approach of a holistic veil all programmes gain consistent value from the stunning views that the Tower has to offer.
Programme: Façade Refurbishment for existing high-rise structure

description:
Contributing to London’s housing needs, the design for Lewisham Gateway aims to rebrand this London district, whilst creating a diverse, active and commercially viable public realm.

The design proposal presents a mixed-use complex, comprised of three residential buildings (for the private rental sector, affordable housing and co-living), a seven-screen cinema, and a series of commercial spaces. Aiming to create high levels of accessibility for the development, significant traffic levels around the site will be negotiated. Rather than becoming an island, the development will anchor a previously disconnected centre with building forms that open outward at the site edges, thereby producing a porous, welcoming and resolutely urban development that draws key pedestrian flows into the site.
title: Lewisham Gateway
concepts:
Concept
Comprised of four blocks, labelled D1, D2, C and E, the complex is characterised by individual architectural profiles, each considering and reflecting Lewisham’s architectural heritage. 

The multi-functional programming of the Lewisham Gateway further enables an extension of the public realm, producing a new public heart for Lewisham. Flexible subdivisions and the unique corner addresses of the podiums will not only attract a broad range of commercial tenancies, the design also envisages the development of leisure and community facilities within the complex, as a result establishing Lewisham Gateway as an attractive location that is vibrant and inclusive for all residents and visitors to the area.

Residential
Blocks D1, D2 and C represent the residential portions of the complex. These residential blocks are designed and orientated in a way that provides maximum daylight, aspect and privacy to the users. The vast majority of units have dual aspect views towards the city, while only a small number have single aspect views. Dual aspect has significant implications on the quality of the residential environment by maximising sunlight and daylight, extending views, allowing privacy and improving air quality in flats. Furthermore, the rational design of the apartments will allow multiple furniture layouts and flexibility for the use of the spaces.

Diverse Programme Mixes
Block C is defined by its mixed programme, complemented with formal diversity and material richness. The block is composed of two taller elements on the southern end containing apartments and to the north, a lower structure containing co-living spaces. These structures are bridged by a large plinth which houses a seven-screen cinema and a number of food & beverage and retail spaces.

Circulation, Access and Connection
Proposed ground floor uses, frontages and entrances have been designed and positioned to reinforce pedestrian flows. In terms of internal access and movement within the blocks, the design of Block E provides a strong structural anchor within the complex, in turn providing a seamless connection to the public space. The design aims to create opportunities for northern access and ultimately to act as an urban generator to the community through its public uses which include 25,000 sq ft of retail space, 15,000 sq ft of restaurants and bars, a gym, and Lewisham’s first major multiplex cinema.

Sustainability
The design aims to extend Lewisham Gateway’s positive insertion into the community by adopting energy and sustainability strategies. The aim of these strategies is to adopt a ‘fabric and energy efficiency first’ approach, followed by the implementation of district heating, and Low and Zero Carbon technologies, to reduce energy consumption and associated carbon emissions. This objective is currently proposed to be achieved through passive design and energy efficiency measures, the implementation of central Combined Heat and Power (CHP) plant, and an array of photovoltaic panels.
Programme: Mixed use: Residential, co-living, co-working, cinema, F&B, retail, gym.

description:
Doraff is a new type of playful furniture that combines the shapes of a dog and a giraffe into a versatile, multifunctional object for children.

At once a table, a chair, a chaise longue and a helping hand to reach high places, Doraff also stimulates the child’s imagination during play. Children can imagine they are riding a giraffe or playing with their dog, or they can easily flip over the lightweight figure to use the differently sized surfaces to play games, read, eat from or simply climb on.

Available in a variety of colours, the robust Doraff is a 100% recyclable thermoplastic resin chair, a hybrid of a furniture piece and a toy, as well as a design object that can be used in a variety of locations.

The Doraff is part of the new kid's collection for Alessi, which also features a children’s cutlery set and tableware.

It's available via Alessi here.
title: Doraff
concepts:
“I have always enjoyed the playfulness of how children perceive and explore the world around them; how the scope of their imagination allows them to think beyond rational boundaries, and how this liberation from logic enables the most creative and wonderfully irrational ideas and perceptions. This is often coupled with intense curiosity, as they try to understand where their imagination ends and ‘the world of the adult’ begins.”

Ben van Berkel, UNStudio's founder and principal architect

description: In collaboration with Amsterdam's Johan Cruijff ArenA, our winning masterplan design for the Korean National Football Centre in Seoul celebrates the history and future of Korean football and the power of sport, in addition to football, the plan also focuses on health, wellness, science, technology and education and promotes a healthy lifestyle. Everything to ensure that South Korean footballers can deliver top performances.
title: Korean National Football Centre
External Team:
Advisors
Amsterdam ArenA – Stadium Logistics and Sports Science: Henk Markerink, Sander van Stiphout, Max Reckers

Visualisations
Brick Visual
concepts:
A Special Relationship: Stronger Together
The Dutch enjoy a successful historical football friendship with South Korea that dates back to 2002, when internationally celebrated Dutch coach Guus Hiddink spectacularly led the South Korean national team to the quarterfinals and a final fourth place - an unprecedented achievement in Korean football history.

For the development of the masterplan, an international team of leading football stadium managers were gathered, alongside specialists in sports science and digital data collection. This team of industry specialists has worked with world-renowned football leagues and stadiums throughout Europe and the Middle East. The essential elements for the masterplan are therefore based on lessons learned from other top international football clubs and training centres.

“The Netherlands is a very proud footballing nation. We have many top players and trainers in teams all over the globe. As the inventors of ‘Total Football’, to us football is not just a sport; it’s an expression of culture, a science and a philosophy. Football brings people together, it provides them with a sense of comradery, of belonging and of national pride.”

- Ben van Berkel, Founder & Principal Architect, UNStudio 

“We are grateful to be chosen for this immensely prestigious project. The Johan Cruijff ArenA is honoured and proud to be part of realising such a prominent and iconic training complex for a country that is advancing technologically in such a way that it serves as an example to us all.

- Henk Markerink, CEO Johan Cruijff ArenA

The Future of Korean Football
Located in Cheonan-shi, Chungnam-do, the masterplan for the new National Football Centre (NFC) envisions the future of Korean football, for which an international presence is crucial.

In the new NFC, the women’s team and youth teams share the facilities with the men’s national team. The youth training facilities are designed to cultivate top league players, with training from international coaches and specific emphasis on the development of their physical and mental health. However, the centre is also designed to become an attractive destination for football fans to enjoy the story of Korean football and use the facilities in order to fully tap into the energy of the league.

Based on the latest insights into sports science and data technology, the National Football Centre will be an exceptional professional football facility housing two stadiums and over a dozen sports field typologies, natural running tracks and indoor gymnasiums. These facilities will be closely linked to the numerous specialist sports medics and treatment centres that will ensure that the athletes can perform at the top of their game.

A high-end hotel with inside and outside lounge areas, spa, sauna and wellness centre will ensure that the NFC also offers exclusive facilities for players to rest and relax before and after training.

The focal point of the masterplan will be the central public plaza, located at the heart of the complex. Here, three primary pieces of architecture - the museum, the indoor stadium and the outdoor stadium - will frame a public pedestrian area that houses restaurants, shops and a variety of (semi) public sports facilities. With its tiered landscape, the large plaza can also host multi-functional events throughout the year.

A New Branding Manual
In addition to the masterplan design, the international competition required that the overall design create a strong brand for the site. In order to ensure cohesiveness throughout the architecture and landscaping of the complex, a novel ‘urban branding manual’ was created. This manual serves as a blueprint for key architectural and urban aspects of the masterplan and outlines specifications for various scales of detail that adhere to the original guiding principles of the design.

The Science of Sport: Health, Wellness, Science and Technology
Together with key sponsors and industry leaders, the NFC training facility will lead the way in sports innovation by focusing on ‘Health, Wellness, Science, and Technology’, forming a branding strategy that also strengthens the commercial position of the facility.

Health
It has recently been discovered that the physical development of young athletes can be improved if they are exposed to a variety of sporting activities that sharpen their motor skills and reflexes. Multiple training and conditioning techniques help improve a player’s performance. For this reason, the new NFC is home to over a dozen various sporting field typologies, natural running tracks, and indoor gymnasiums.

Wellness
Mental health is closely linked to the physical body’s development and nourishment. As a result, the campus not only provides facilities for the players to rest, relax and relieve stress, the material palette is derived from this essential driver. Where possible, local natural materials of raw and exposed stone, timber, and textiles are employed, while an abundance of vegetation and green space is provided, thus embedding the campus into the surrounding landscape of farmland and hills sides.

Science and Technology
Investing in the next generation of athletes is key to the success of any sports programme. The NFC will therefore become a laboratory for, not only training the first national team, but also for the training of youth leagues and woman’s teams involved in the sport. This collective gathering of various levels of athletes will provide sports medicine scientists with the wide-ranging data they need to evaluate and custom tailor different training regimens.

Digital technology has permeated sports allowing coaches, management and health care services to track the progress and development of sports programs yielding the greatest results from their facilities. The UNStudio team has specific knowledge of discretely integrating digital technology into the built environment for data collection related to the user’s health, activity, time and schedule allocation, in addition to other bio-metrics.
Programme: Campus Masterplan and Urban Branding Strategy, 1 Outdoor Stadium with management facilities (1000-1500 Seats), 1 Indoor Stadium with support facilities, The National Team health and resort facility, Museum for Korean Football, supporting training fields and recreation, youth hostel and retail.

description:
CityLife is an ambitious commercial and residential development on Milan’s historic former trade fair grounds: the Fiera Milano. The development has a strong focus on sustainability: ‘smart’ buildings with high energy performance, a car-free zone and a diversity of developed public and green spaces. It would also become the second largest green park in Milan.

The brief for the CityLife International Design Competition was to complete the development by designing the last two remaining plots, with the urban area in between. To add this last chapter to CityLife, it was essential to understand the importance of the project as an urban and real estate development. After thorough analysis, UNStudio proposed to aim for a finely crafted, high performance urban campus and create diversity in both function and architecture, as well as form a stronger transition between the existing urban fabric and the connecting neighbourhoods.

UNStudio’s concept is data-driven and based on variables that define efficiency, constructability, flexibility, sustainability and wellbeing, with an overall emphasis on craftsmanship. The design is centred around people and focusses on the comfort and wellbeing of each person who would work in, live in or simply pass by CityLife. The design offers a memorable and engaging space; a healthy recreational and working environment. The proposal encompasses physical, mental, social and environmental health. The new campus layout aims to result in a framework for the built environment and space where elements and solutions are human-centric and implement the most progressive level of engineering, innovation and sustainability.
title: CityLife, International Design Competition Parcel Re & Rd
External Team:
Advisors
Architect of Record/ Local Architect: SBGA
Environmental Design, Structural Engineering, Building Services, Façade Engineering, Acoustics Engineering Services: Arup   
Mobility: MIC – Mobility in Chain
Landscape: Green4Cities
Fire Safety: Studio Mistretta & Co
Cost Estimation: GAD
Visualisations: Studio Negativ, AAND3
concepts:
Urban Regeneration
The newly proposed buildings are predominantly different from their surroundings. A new resolution and quality is introduced in the architecture and the landscape. The aim is to attract different user types to CityLife in order to create social diversity. The target of all design decisions is to establish quality space for people to dwell and to engage with; space which will engender strong emotional attachments, which form the cornerstone of community building. Attractive and comfortable workspaces, public space and intimate green areas that people will want to return to time and time again, and a memorable hotel. The design aims to connect people and strengthen CityLife’s position as a Milan destination for visitors and locals alike. The design subtly relates to the former fairground; its aim to entertain, the playfulness of its details and Its social accessibility.

Spatial Experience
The two towers are shaped by consciously set programmatic intentions. The volumes reflect the changes in the spatial requirements of the interiors and their functions. The facade openings signal changes in function, while connecting the indoor and outdoor environments. Social spaces are clustered in the large gestures of the volumes in order to activate the buildings vertically and create space for interaction. These spaces also introduce a biophilic green environment to the interior.

The indoor environment is inspired by traditional Milanese interiors and uses only circular materials, which support the zero energy target. The interior is designed to be a responsive environment where specific elements are in dialogue with the users. For instance the lighting is controlled by occupancy, but can also be personalised it in the common spaces. The data analysis based monitoring of the spaces makes operations efficient and the user experience bespoke.

A hotel is located in the higher tower at the top of the development, thereby fully utilising the potential of the CityLife site. The design of the hotel originates from traditional Milanese courtyards. The lobby is located in a floating garden that expands through the hotel volume, floating above the entire office block and CityLife. Upon arrival, visitors find themselves in a semi-outdoor, green and lush garden. All of the hotel rooms are accessed from this space, which also offers the most spectacular views of Milan.

Future of Workspace
UNStudio’s proposal offers a flexible and efficient framework to accommodate changing future needs and a variety of potential tenants and users. The two buildings both apply a vertical social campus concept where workspace is clustered around community, thereby enhancing interaction, creativity and engagement between users. These social gathering spaces - visible in the appearance of the towers - are the heart and soul of the buildings. They are strengthened by their connection to the exterior and with green areas which further blur the boundaries of interior and exterior and increase the performance, motivation and efficiency of the users.

The workspace is designed to serve three main different types of activity, in order to guarantee flexibility of usage. Typical cccupants are freelancers, entrepreneurs, start-ups and small teams that require dynamic, versatile and varied workspaces.  A personalised environment, alongside communication suites includes both individual and group workspaces.

Formal office layouts per floor - that are supported by optimal daylight conditions - include small break-out spaces for social interaction. This layout is optimised for focused work where full concentration is required.

The collaborative office levels are designed to foster workplace communities and teamwork. Circulation and workplace zones are arranged to encourage interaction and communication. High flexibility and a diversity of spaces provide the opportunity to attract different users.

The design of creative workspace revolves around the concept of ‘encountering’. As such the CityLife workspaces are designed to inspire; to provide a catalyst for spontaneous interactions and the exchange of ideas. These offices are a combination of shared individual and teamwork spaces, which are linked visually to stimulate social activity and accelerate the generation of innovation.

A Sustainable Approach
Our vision for CityLife also included sustainable and circular design features, with the aim to make the development more green.

As part of this, we included rainwater harvesting provisions, grey water recycling facilities, urban farming areas, and solar panels on the rooves. We also applied specific orientations to the buildings to reduce solar radiation.
