description:
UNStudio’s proposal for the New Port District in Turku explores how we can live with water in the 21st century. It will be an interface, where urbanity and nature meet and coexist.

Three distinct urban areas are proposed, consisting of new and existing urban anchors and highlighting the potential of maritime areas. The areas are united by a multifunctional and attractive shoreline that not only protects, but also offers diversity for both nature and people.

Like the medieval Turku Castle in the past, the new Turku Maritime District will be a catalyst for new innovations and cultural developments. Connecting the city and the sea, our proposal for a new waterfront hub consists of three main areas: ‘Port City’, with a proposal to relocate Turku Fair Centre and blue marine businesses; ‘Museum Gardens’, which combines the Castle and a new Museum, and the ‘Maritime Quarter’, with local restaurants and new types of waterfront housing.
title: Linnanniemi Waterfront Masterplan
External Team:
Advisors
Co-designers: Lunden Architecture
Landscape, engineering, mobility, sustainability: WSP
History: Panu Savolainen (University of Turku)
CGI Visuals: Plomp
keywords: A Landmark of the Finnish Archipelago
concepts:
Diverse and Active Waterfront District
Given its prime location and history, Linnanniemi has the potential to become the new centre of maritime culture, innovation and ecology. The proposed functions are based on and enhance existing valuable characteristics of the site. They also bring activities that can be enjoyed 24/7, all year round.

Port City: New home for the Turku Fair and Blue Marine Businesses
Port City is an industrial and innovative quarter dedicated to international events, marine industry, business and research. It provides a unique site for the relocated Turku Fair Centre, is connected to local and international transportation networks and surrounded by a new Hotel and Congress Centre and ferry terminal. While exhibition spaces, street food and bars take over ground floors, upper floors accommodate growing marine businesses.

Museum Gardens: All-year-round Cultural and Natural Heart
The Museum Gardens is an all-year-round cultural, recreational and biodiverse attraction that creates a unique setting for large-scale outdoor events. The concentrated green and pedestrian-oriented area brings together historic and new structures. The new Museum is an extension of the Castle and linked by pavilions and relocated storehouses. The gardens offer a lush and dynamic shorefront that showcases the biodiverse marine environment.

Maritime Quarter: Finland's New Culinary Destination
The Maritime Quarter is a new pedestrian area combining famous local cuisine and bistros with maritime history, waterfront housing and smaller cultural outdoor venues. Its sheltered shorefront between Hostel Borea and Suomen Joutsen offers a variety of water activities, such as outdoor swimming, boating and floating stages, generating a new hyggelig small-scale area that attracts both locals and tourists from Finland and abroad.

A Landmark of the Finnish Archipelago
The new Museum is strategically located at the mouth of the River Aura, welcoming all travellers to the new Maritime District and City of Turku. As part of a dynamic waterfront, the museum area transforms into an island, becoming an extension of the Finnish Archipelago when the water rises. Its iconic location offers the possibility for an exciting dialogue with the Turku Castle, which is further enhanced with vibrant green spaces and repurposed wooden houses situated between the two destinations. With simple geometries offering spectacular panoramic views, the new Museum seeks to create an elegant new landmark that complements rather than competes with the Castle’s historic architecture.

description:
In recent years, wellness has become a central focus in many people’s lifestyles, influencing and guiding the way they interact with the world. In prioritising their physical and mental wellbeing, people also look to their built environments and how these spaces impact on their health and comfort. Core to this is their homes.

UNStudio’s experience design team, UNSx, was commissioned by heritage German sanitary ware manufacturer Kaldewei to explore how an increased focus on wellness could influence bathrooms of the future, and to use this research to define development scenarios for the brand, taking into consideration any needs for changes in the product offering, the business model, and the customer experience strategy.

To do this, we used co-creative workshops with the Kaldewei team to answer four key questions: how can we turn bathrooms into experience rooms? How will changing demographics influence user needs around bathroom products? What role will new technologies have in the bathroom? Will technology enable us to turn the bathroom from a place of necessity into a personalised space of calm and convenience?
title: Kaldewei Bathroom Experiences
UNStudio Team: William de Boer and Machteld Kors
External Team:
Advisors
PWC
Cosima Geyer
concepts:
The Work Process
To look towards the future of bathrooms, we first went back to the very essence of what these rooms are used for – bathing. This ritualistic activity can be a rejuvenating and calming experience, but it can also bring hassle and stress.

Two key areas that can induce this are the cleaning process, which is more demanding than other rooms in the home, especially for family units, and safety for elderly people. We used these areas as the basis for a series of co-creative workshops in which we gathered designers, product managers, and strategists in the world of bathrooms, spa, and hammams to come up with solutions that would make the bathroom experience more enjoyable for everyone.

The first workshop focused on the scenario of improving the convenience of the cleaning process, particularly for elderly users. The second was concentrated on young families who struggle with raising kids and managing household duties. The third speculated on the use of new technology in the bathroom experience, such as augmented reality and voice interface.

Customising Bathroom Experiences
The process resulted in an experience concept and a mock-up for an app that could customise the bathroom environment to individual preferences. The concept bridges sensory experiences related to touch, light and temperature with bathroom products, and includes a digital interface that configures the environment to optimise the experience for health and wellbeing.

description:
Joined by researchers from Wageningen University & Research and TU Delft, UNSx hosted an interactive workshop on climate adaptation and health outcomes at the CLICKNL DRIVE Festival, held during Dutch Design Week in October 2019.

The aim of the workshop was to introduce the climatic factors at play in urban environments and their myriad effects on health outcomes, and in turn to discuss possible ways to intervene for the community’s advantage.

Amongst a wide array of physical climatic measures, the workshop focused on heat and wind. The former because it induces stress and reduces mobility, and the latter because it discourages walking and cycling, in turn encouraging auto use, even for short trips.
title: CLICKNL Climate Design Workshop
External Team:
Wageningen University & Research
Karolina Doughty, Sanda Lenzholzer, Yvette Buist

TU Delft
Froukje Sleeswijk-Visser
concepts:
Interactive Simulation
To better illustrate the link between our living environment and health, participants engaged in an interactive simulation activity that examined Meerzicht, a socioeconomically disadvantaged neighbourhood in Zoetermeer, 17km northeast of the centre of The Hague. Through this activity, participants had to determine appropriate solutions to the urban scenarios and reflect on potential health implications.

We divided participants into groups of four and gave each a set of tools consisting of a satellite overview map of Meerzicht, rolls of tape and a set of cards. Each card included a method of urban intervention and climate adaptation, including propositions of heat regulation and uphold of ventilation in public spaces. With the given examples, our moderators led the participants in a discussion of the advantages and disadvantages of proposing these interventions for certain public areas.

The Outcome
During the workshop, we found that each group honed in on different issues in Meerzicht. One group started off by making distinctions between ‘short term’ and ‘long term’ climate adaptation strategies, and pursued a strategy that coincided more with the long-term vision: creating a New York-style ‘High Line’ of the current NS railway. By burying train tracks underground, the group wagered the elevated green walkway could not only provide a new space for leisure and exercise, but also spur a new sense of belonging in Meerzicht residents.

Another group focused on the health outcomes of their interventions and prioritised the need for high-quality public spaces in the city, proposing piazzas with fountains that would create opportunities for social engagement and meanwhile cool the air through water evaporation. Their proposal stressed the need for communal involvement, particularly advocating for inclusive neighbourhood initiatives.

The third group confers from the perspective of playfulness and adaptability, and places a priority in responding to the question ‘what kind of society do we want to strive for?’ The group considered the approach of adaptability through looking at varying climatic conditions and their relation to nature. They conferred that the introduction of new, leafy trees will support both wind dampening and air-cooling in the spring and summer, whilst their barren state in the autumn and winter means flexible awnings could be considered as an additional measure to offer protection from rain.

Despite the tight time constraint, participants were able to come up and successfully deliver ideas that went beyond small-scale intervention to tackle climate issues. Together, the groups developed a long-term vision for Meerzicht, a neighbourhood for today’s residents and tomorrow’s generations.

description:
UNStudio was appointed to design the masterplan and architecture for the new Mandarin Oriental Hotel and Residences in Etiler, a prestigious residential quarter on the European side of Istanbul, located close to the city’s central business district.

The 216,740 m2 development comprises three high-rise towers (2 residential, 1 hotel) that merge with lush green landscaped gardens. 3 storey high commercial podia house offices, retail and restaurants and are located above 3 levels of underground parking.
title: Mandarin Oriental Hotel and Residences
External Team:
Visualisations
Methanoia
Zoa
concepts:
Programme
The three towers within the development accommodate different living typologies. One of the towers will house the Mandarin Oriental Etiler Hotel, with 158 guestrooms and suites and 16 serviced apartments. The remaining two towers will house numerous residences at Mandarin Oriental.

The hotel will have three restaurants and bars, a selection of adaptable meeting spaces with outdoor areas and terraces, a spa and fitness centre, and both an indoor and outdoor swimming pool. The residences at Mandarin Oriental will enjoy direct access to the hotel’s facilities, in addition to bespoke resident facilities, which include two outdoor swimming pools and a fitness centre.

The commercial plinth comprises retail shops, offices and public amenities. It extends to three levels below the garden level and is accessible directly from the commercial plaza entrance at Selcuklar Sk.

The Urban Plan
With its unique topography, the beauty of Bosporus and the amalgamation of different cultures throughout the centuries, Istanbul provides its residents with a varied and rich quality of life. This new mixed-use development in Etiler reflects the contemporary lifestyle of both local and international people who want to be part of this vibrant and modern metropolis.

The site is located in the district of Beşiktaş, close to the business quarters of Levent and Maslak and within easy walking distance of Akmerkez shopping mall. The three entrances to the project are formed by the hotel lobby at the southern tip of the site, the residential lobby that faces inwards for privacy, and the commercial plaza entrance. There is also a three-level parking area below the commercial plinth which services the residences, the hotel and the public programme.

Taking advantage of the existing slope on the site, the podium appears to be partially tucked underground. This gesture not only reduces the impact of the volume at the urban scale, but also enables the lush garden area to be highly visible to the whole neighborhood, thereby adding to the quality of living in Etiler.

Green, Well-Being & Health
The starting point for the design of the urban plan was to create a large lush garden that provides a unique experience for the residents, as well as for the surrounding neighbourhood. The full landscaped area of 31,885 m2 is used for the garden, which becomes the reference point for the whole design. The garden accentuates the feeling of spaciousness and connectivity, while providing a varied landscape with activity areas for both the residents and guests.

The garden is the unifying plane of the whole project. With a single gesture, it extends upwards to the towers, creating numerous dedicated garden terraces for the special residences. It signifies the transition from the shared area - with facilities that include two outdoor pools and several pavilions - to the privately owned areas, which enjoy private pools alongside areas of paving and green.

The garden is intended to empower healthy living; the design amplifies active circulation, while providing opportunities for exercise alongside a multitude of green spaces in which residents can live, work and play in local proximity. The large garden is designed as a place for gathering and a space for physical and psychological comfort and stimulation.

Sculpted Living
The design of the towers plays a key role in the implementation of sustainability measures, which begin with the massing. Their placement is the result of parametric testing to find an optimal position that would avoid casting shadows on each other and on the garden in the afternoon hours, and minimise any impact on the surrounding neighbourhood. The facade length is also maximised in order to provide all residences with views over the Bosporus waterway.

The form of the towers results in a sculpted, fanning effect. The top floors gradually step inwards at the side with the most prominent views, in order to allow for larger penthouse terraces. The central levels, which form the core of the tower, host most of the residences. Meanwhile, the lower floors, where the fanning is most evident, establish the connection with the garden.

The fanning enables the towers to seamlessly merge with the garden, as the two elements come together to provide a healthy biophilic element that increases the occupants’ connectivity to the natural environment.

Villa Living in the Sky
To ensure stunning views on all sides of the site, we introduced a glass facade that wraps around the towers. A horizontal ribbon then winds around each floor and introduces variety to the balustrade design.

The terraces also contribute significantly to the reduction of the heat load on the large glass surfaces of the towers. Aside from the terraces, a continuous French Balcony surrounds the full plan, providing access to all rooms. This means all rooms can also enjoy natural ventilation, while apartments have the opportunity to cross-ventilate, thereby reducing the need for air-conditioning and lowering energy usage.

To accentuate the individuality of each residence, each terrace extends or recesses in relation to the terrace above it. As a result, every resident enjoys a double-height outdoor living space, creating an experience of villa living in the sky of Istanbul.

Designing with Craftsmanship
The aim of the facade design for the Mandarin Oriental Hotel and Residences is to employ materials that portray artistry, wherein hand-craftsmanship is evident in the quality of the design and workmanship. Metalwork, pottery, ceramics and woodwork, become the references for the principal materials used in the project.

The anthracite ribbons are clad with glazed ceramic tiles, inspired by centuries of tradition and knowledge, in addition to a multicultural mixture of influences. These tiles are cast in such a way as to catch the light differently across the course of the day.

In addition, bronze details throughout the project give the feeling of both tradition and exclusivity. Such details are employed in the lobby areas and in the ceiling design of the terraces.

A sense of place at the commercial entrance is achieved by introducing wooden frame elements. The detailing of the frames not only incorporate the technical requirements for ventilation, but also reflect the honing of the design to achieve a natural and tactile environment.
Programme: Mixed use Podium with offices, retail and restaurants (3 floors, 15m high) 2 luxury residential towers (32 floors each, 150m high) and 1 hotel tower (37 floors, 170m high) with serviced apartments Parking (3 basement levels, 1368 parking spaces)

description: Our proposal for The Cloud @ Donaumarina is a sustainable and dynamic architectural ambition that creates a new benchmark for working environments in Vienna. The Donaumarina District along the river Danube is currently defined by a mosaic of building proportions and programmes, ranging from small-scale houses to high-rise offices, all within close proximity to each other. In response to these existing contrasts, The Cloud @ Donaumarina rotates facade volumes at different heights, allowing the building to connect and integrate appropriately with its surroundings. The facade interchanges from smaller human-scale volumes along the pedestrian level to bigger volumes at the top, creating a unique addition to the waterfront skyline. Together with its neighboring tower, it creates an urban ensemble in the city’s rapidly developing Donaumarina District.
title: The Cloud @ Donaumarina
External Team:
Advisors
Bolliger + Grohmann Ingenieure (Structure, Façade, Building Physics)
Transsolar (Sustainability)
FireX (Fire protection)
Engram (Visualisations)
concepts:
Design Concept
While many office towers are often indifferent to their context, The Cloud proposes a design that responds to its surroundings and to the people at work within. Inside the building, strategically rotated volumes create dynamic spaces of work, with a floorplate that provides corner offices for all workers. Furthermore, all spaces within the building can be customised and enhanced through a curated set of spatial plugins which are interchangeable on any floorplate. From the outside, the pedestrian eye level is brought to a human scale through more frequent facade rotations, attracting the public realm into the building. Larger rotated volumes elevated above the neighbouring buildings offer bigger floorplates, which respond accordingly to the scale of the surrounding city and landscapes.

The Wooden Workplace
In order to create a sustainable tower that prioritises the health and well-being of its users, the majority of The Cloud is made from wood. Visible wooden floors, columns and beams create a warm interior atmosphere. Together with a concrete core and steel beams along the edges, the tower rises up to 103 meters. If built, it would become the tallest timber high-rise in Austria. To ensure that the wooden structure is also visible from the outside, the design introduces a system of motorised wooden shutters along the facade that protect the interior from too much sunlight, while at the same saving energy when closed.

The Silver Lining
Taking inspiration from cloud computing, The Cloud is a network of wooden volumes wrapped in glass, creating an open and transparent space that connects to its surroundings. Holding the health and wellbeing of its users at its core, The Cloud helps working communities to connect to each other. Nodes of single protruding units shape new working environments, generating a unique identity and community for the Donaumarina District.

description:
Joined by researchers from Wageningen University & Research and TU Delft, UNSx hosted an interactive workshop on climate adaptation and health outcomes at the CLICKNL DRIVE Festival, held during Dutch Design Week in October 2019.

The aim of the workshop was to introduce the climatic factors at play in urban environments and their myriad effects on health outcomes, and in turn to discuss possible ways to intervene for the community’s advantage.

Amongst a wide array of physical climatic measures, the workshop focused on heat and wind. The former because it induces stress and reduces mobility, and the latter because it discourages walking and cycling, in turn encouraging auto use, even for short trips.
title: CLICKNL Climate Design Workshop
External Team:
Wageningen University & Research
Karolina Doughty, Sanda Lenzholzer, Yvette Buist

TU Delft
Froukje Sleeswijk-Visser
concepts:
Interactive Simulation
To better illustrate the link between our living environment and health, participants engaged in an interactive simulation activity that examined Meerzicht, a socioeconomically disadvantaged neighbourhood in Zoetermeer, 17km northeast of the centre of The Hague. Through this activity, participants had to determine appropriate solutions to the urban scenarios and reflect on potential health implications.

We divided participants into groups of four and gave each a set of tools consisting of a satellite overview map of Meerzicht, rolls of tape and a set of cards. Each card included a method of urban intervention and climate adaptation, including propositions of heat regulation and uphold of ventilation in public spaces. With the given examples, our moderators led the participants in a discussion of the advantages and disadvantages of proposing these interventions for certain public areas.

The Outcome
During the workshop, we found that each group honed in on different issues in Meerzicht. One group started off by making distinctions between ‘short term’ and ‘long term’ climate adaptation strategies, and pursued a strategy that coincided more with the long-term vision: creating a New York-style ‘High Line’ of the current NS railway. By burying train tracks underground, the group wagered the elevated green walkway could not only provide a new space for leisure and exercise, but also spur a new sense of belonging in Meerzicht residents.

Another group focused on the health outcomes of their interventions and prioritised the need for high-quality public spaces in the city, proposing piazzas with fountains that would create opportunities for social engagement and meanwhile cool the air through water evaporation. Their proposal stressed the need for communal involvement, particularly advocating for inclusive neighbourhood initiatives.

The third group confers from the perspective of playfulness and adaptability, and places a priority in responding to the question ‘what kind of society do we want to strive for?’ The group considered the approach of adaptability through looking at varying climatic conditions and their relation to nature. They conferred that the introduction of new, leafy trees will support both wind dampening and air-cooling in the spring and summer, whilst their barren state in the autumn and winter means flexible awnings could be considered as an additional measure to offer protection from rain.

Despite the tight time constraint, participants were able to come up and successfully deliver ideas that went beyond small-scale intervention to tackle climate issues. Together, the groups developed a long-term vision for Meerzicht, a neighbourhood for today’s residents and tomorrow’s generations.

description:
In recent decades, Indonesia’s capital of Jakarta has developed into a city with a cosmopolitan spirit and an international outlook. UNStudio’s interpretation of a new high-rise tower for this bustling metropolis takes into account the city’s future-proofing ambitions, whilst providing balanced building that honours the skyline.

Located on the intersection of the city’s two most-important streets (Sudirman and Gatot Subroto), the development features a memorable silhouette that will make it a landmark for Jakarta. With its slim profile and towering height, the design plays with geometry transformation and uses expressive markings, seamless details and a calm palette of materials to create a timeless and recognisable skyscraper.

Inspired by human movement and touch, the design embraces raw local materials while experimenting with the latest technology. Its most iconic feature is the SKY FOREST, a green core running up the centre of the tower, which sets a novel benchmark of positive urban impact and circular ecology. As a future-proof development, this indoor forest is just one of the sustainable features included in our design to address the issues of a lack of green space and air pollution in Jakarta.
title: Mangkuluhur City Tower II
concepts:
Vertical Neighbourhoods
Our ambition with the design is to shape an attractive, lively, mixed-use and economically meaningful high-rise space, which allows for unexpected encounters and extreme escapism.

Across the 350-metre-high tower we included numerous programmes, including a 2,500-capacity ballroom, an observation deck, 58 levels of offices, 22 levels of apartments as well as space for a hotel and parking. In order to encourage a sense of community in the space, we created public spaces for each programme within the building, all served by the SKY FOREST.

The facade has an overlapping texture to create shadow play and a finer reading when in close proximity, while the building lands onto the site with a gesture that echoes the geometry of the forest amenity area and repurposes it as an open and welcoming portal towards the ground floor lobby.

The SKY FOREST
The building framework for the Jakarta Tower was designed around the iconic SKY FOREST, a green core inspired by the surrounding landscape. Living up to its name, the indoor forest is a space of wonder and excitement, filled with lush, tropical trees and vegetation that is integrated into the architecture.

Our intention for this striking feature is to create a “second ground” in the sky, not only serving as the most prominent element of the tower but also setting a new paradigm of positive urban impact and circular ecology. Functionally, we designed an urban yet tropical park for residents where they can enjoy nature and the mezzanine of shared amenities, including a fully equipped gym. It also serves an essential function in the air circulation and purification in the building (see environmental responsibilities below).

Sustainability and Environmental Responsibility
The facade: In order to optimise sustainable constructions in the future, buildings should no longer be seen as mere energy saving or energy efficient structures. New technologies enable us to change buildings into energy harvesting vehicles with enhanced aesthetics and operability.

Solar Visuals, a revolutionary new cladding material brought to you by UNStudio’s daughter company UNSense, TNO and printing specialist TS Visuals, allowed for the building to be transformed into a battery without losing aesthetic appeal.

Using a patented dot printing software technology, Solar Visuals is capable of translating images into a setup of dots of different coverage ratios, controlling colour, contrast, brightness and a degree of randomness in the final effect. In doing so, it allows for these solar panels to be fully customised, creating visually appealing opportunities for large-scale energy production in the built environment.

The SKY FOREST: The tower’s green core is an integral component in our approach to purifying the air within the development. Acting as a natural smog filtration system, the indoor forest is paired with state-of-the-art technology located in the plant room below to create a system that will clean the air and circulate it throughout the entire building.

The core: Grey water from the hotel and residential components of the design will be treated and cleaned on site through packaged systems with living machines. All recycled greywater will be used to irrigate outdoor and indoor greenery, and for sanitary use in the office and podium spaces.
Programme: Mixed-use tower (Office, Residential, Hotel, Observation Deck)

description: Both Siemens and Berlin are transforming. In order to take advantage of its competitive edge as a creative, young city, and in order to bolster its position as a competitive brand, both Berlin and Siemens must provide agile, flexible and unique environments that can attract talent, while ensuring a sustainable and healthy lifestyle.
title: Siemensstadt 2.0 Masterplan
keywords: A Smart Ecological Framework – the Siemens Zigzag
concepts:
Creating a Unique Urban Identity
The plan pays special attention to public spaces, streets, green spaces and plazas, and to shared public buildings, making them safe and inclusive to all ages and genders. By celebrating historic buildings such as Verwaltungsgebauede, Schaltwerkhallen and Schaltwerkhochhaus while also introducing new urban elements into the development, the plan becomes the point of convergence between the past and the future, defining its urban identity urban as a transition between new and old.

A Smart Ecological Framework – the Siemens Zigzag
Responding directly to the ecological challenges of the site and its surrounding urban environment, the proposal outlines an ecological framework that revitalises nature on site and offsets industrial and urban development impacts. The ecological spine – the Siemens Zigzag, is an inclusive public space that serves as an ecological engine that includes trees and flowerbeds, water retention ponds and urban gardens. As such, it invites a rich, biodiverse host of pollinators and fauna into the site, while creating a destination for leisure and sports. The Zigzag also functions as the Smart backbone of the development, providing an independent data infrastructure that supports its mobility services, and its users at home and at work.
Programme: Residential, office/labs, Sports and Recreation, Retail, Hospitality, Education, Urban Farm, smart grid

description:
Xintiandi Plaza is located in the heart of Shanghai, along the well-known Huai Hai Road, and functions as an entrance gate to the buzzing Xintiandi area. Huai Hai Road and Xintiandi are fast becoming the most popular and famous shopping and entertainment areas in Shanghai, forming as they do both a local and an international retail destination.

Xintiandi Plaza is designed to provide a lifestyle destination for Shanghai’s young professionals. Combining retail, restaurants and themed spaces, all arranged in a novel organisation, Xintiandi Plaza steps away from the typical mall and towards a vertical city centre layout that provides opportunities for shopping, strolling, eating, gathering and relaxing.
title: Xintiandi Plaza
External Team:
Advisors
Local Design Institute: Tianhua
Facade: Inhabit
Lighting: ag licht / LEOX
Landscape: TianHua landscape
Interior Design shop drawings: DPDI

Photography
© Terrence Zhang
concepts:
Gateway to Xintiandi
In collaboration with Shui On Land – owners of both the Shui On Plaza and the Xintiandi developments – a strategy was established to turn the Shui On plaza into the gateway to the Xintiandi area, thereby enabling a transition and fusion of the international high-end fashion street Huai Hai Road and the traditional small scale Shikumen architecture lifestyle and F&B area.

The main concept for the Xintiandi Plaza design is to compile and compose these differing local characteristics within one building. This is achieved by stacking them vertically to create a landscape of different experiences. These experiences will be placed within the building envelope in key positions that are visible from the street, thereby allowing a glimpse of the activities taking place within and blurring the boundaries between the inside and outside space.

Inside the mall, elements of outdoor street life are mixed with lifestyle retail features and are distributed throughout the building. Resembling a leisurely stroll outside, this organisation encourages the visitor to wander through and explore the different levels of the building, where retail spaces follow an open layout and are punctuated with small kiosks.

Banded inside-out
The cylindrical tower geometry from the north-west corner of the existing building gives rise to the idea of undulating bands that define the building and determine the breakdown of the volume. These bands further create terraces and connect to the plaza and the street level. In the interior, the bands form atria and create a variety of activity spaces. Exterior and interior space are therefore controlled by the bands, which connect programme and activities by seamlessly moving through the facade layer and continuing into the interior.

In addition to this horizontal interconnectivity, several spaces are also connected in a vertical direction. The sunken plaza located towards Huai Hai Road connects the street level to the basement metro entry, while stacked balconies connect the ground level all the way to the roof garden. All platforms, terraces and outdoor spaces are planted with lush vegetation in order to create a new green urban landscape for this vertical city centre concept.

Facade
Matching the existing stone facade of the building - which will remain on the tower levels - and referencing the Shikumen brick used in Xintiandi, the dominant solid material used in the facade is terracotta. The high quality metallic finish of the terracotta tiles complements the glamourous atmosphere on Huai Hai Road. The use of the latest production techniques also ensures that the tiles form a very strong and durable facade material.

Interior
Bringing the outside landscape into the inside of the building creates a natural, organic effect, which is also evident in the interior design. Here the magnolia - Shanghai’s patron flower – is applied as a recurring motif. At the numerous access points to the mall, this flower motif is integrated into the backlit ceilings and is reimagined for use throughout the building, with columns inspired by the magnolia reaching all the way to the top of the building. These ‘flower columns’ are the central design feature of the mall and provide the visual connection between the different levels and spaces in the interior.

Two voids cut through the building volume and allow for a generous influx of natural daylight and ample views, which open up all the way from the second basement level to the top floor. The main diagonal void includes several plateaus that strengthen the idea of nature and organic structures when seen from below. Viewed from above they reveal flexibly programmable retail spaces.

The escalator void organises the vertical circulation and orientation. It creates view lines across the different levels and facilitates an unobstructed view column from the ground floor up to the skylight. The spiraling handrail surrounding the void guides the visitor to the next escalator. It further connects the voids and the different visitor routes, while carrying people through the building past a variety of activities and the magnolia columns. Finally, it culminates with the top level garden dining experience and the roof top garden.

From both inside and out, the experience of Xintiandi Plaza will become a memorable one along Huai Hai road, acting as a stand-alone lifestyle retail experience, as well as the gateway to Xintiandi.

description: EZ Parque da Cidade in São Paulo introduces a new form of living to Brazil by way of landscape-oriented design, community-activated pavilions and panoramic floorplans.
title: EZ Parque da Cidade
External Team:
Advisors
Executive Architect: Alexandre Milleu Arquitetura
Legal Project: Carlos Eduardo Monteiro
Interior Architect: III Interior Design by Triptyque Architecture
Landscape: Sergio Santana Planejamento e Desenho da Paisagem
Structure: Pasqua & Graziano Associados
Fitness and Gym: CIA Athletica

Visualisations
ZOA and Neorama
concepts:
Rotating Clusters
Unlike the more typical high-rise residential buildings found in Brazil - which comprise back-to-back units with single directional views - in the Parque da Cidade an innovative rotating ‘windmill’-shaped floorplan allows each apartment unit to benefit from 4-sided panoramic views and optimal sun orientation, while all the while ensuring maximum privacy by avoiding visual connections between units.

Pavilions in the Park
Residents of the EZ Parque da Cidade can enjoy walks through the lush landscape at ground and mezzanine levels, punctuated by a series of programmatic pavilions. From the top of the canopy that connects the two residential towers, the view opens up towards the Parque da Cidade public park as a spectacular backdrop, while the concept of the pavilions is continued into the towers in the form of sky gardens.

Each of the 8 sky gardens have large lush terraces of Bougainvillea with their own distinctive colours, to create a sense of identity across the different vertical communities. The sky gardens encourage communal experiences within the towers and are integrated with a Wellness Lounge, a Gourmet Lounge, a Sky Bar, and an Entertainment lounge, all of which offer exceptional views towards the city and the nearby water of Sao Paulo’s Pinheiros river.

Unprecedented Sustainability Certifications
The project has been awarded the AQUA Certification (Brazilian certification adapted from the original French ‘Démarche HQE’) for its highest environmental performance and contribution to the improvement of the quality of life of its users, while the Masterplan Parque da Cidade is the first development in South America to receive LEED-ND Neighbourhood pre-certification for its impact on the neighbourhood in terms of community, health and local sustainability.
Programme: 39 storey and 36 storey high-end residential towers. 244 residential units, with sky bar, entertainment lounge, sky gourmet lounge, wellness & yoga lounge in the towers. Other public amenities include a spa, fitness, squash room, indoor and outdoor pools, library, study room, kids play room, teens room, party room, outdoor solarium, tennis court, kids room, gourmet barbeque area, pet playground.

description: UNStudio’s urban vision for the 11,660,320 m² Xingdong New Area puts people and nature first. The urban plan 'Green City Blue City' conveys an ecological green/blue network that simultaneously values economic prosperity and the users’ physical, psychological and social well-being. The plan ultimately encourages the Green (nature and landscape) and the Blue (water) to overtake the Grey (buildings and infrastructure).
title: Xingdong New Area
concepts:
Urban Pillars
The strong bearing towards nature came about upon the consideration of Xingtai’s history and culture. As the area is and has always been closely tied to rivers, the starting point of the project very quickly oriented towards designing the future city along the river.
With these goals in mind, UNStudio’s vision adheres to five key urban pillars that would transform and shape Xingdong New Area into a resilient urban environment. The five urban pillars refer to the principles of five C’s – Connectivity, Creativity, Cleanliness, Community and Cleverness. Connectivity refers to creating physical and social connections within the system; Creativity refers to the fostering of innovation and the making of room for culture, arts and new industries; Cleanliness refers to maintaining of a safe and clean environment; Community refers to the pursuance of interactive experiences; and Clever, refers to the emergence of a sensor-based city that is smart and flexible.

New Communities
Xingdong New Area is a place for people. For the ease of navigation, UNStudio proposed to develop and divide the city into five different neighbourhoods, each with its own identity, corresponding dominant typologies and supporting amenities. The five neighbourhoods correspond to five different potential user groups: the Artists, the Educators, the Makers, the Innovators and the Urbanists.
Xingdong New Area will bring 200,000 new residents and 2,500,000 daily commuters into the new district, increasing the current urban population by 70%. Taking into consideration this large influx of people and goods, UNStudio’s urban plan envisages maximizing social comfort by introducing a sense of belonging and overall well-being amongst the new communities.
Catering to the users’ wellbeing and adhering to the principle of sustainability, Xingdong New Area is designed as a walkable district, which encourages people to live a healthy and active lifestyle in the long run. Amenities are located at a close and convenient proximity: all residential units are located within a 10-minute walk to parks and shops. In favouring pedestrians, all streets are equipped with wide sidewalks, and at the core of the district, there is a designated ‘Eco Spine’ zone that will remain vehicle-free.
In terms of urban life, different key moments are plugged into the masterplan to further enhance urban qualities, whilst encouraging social interactions and the development of new iconic destinations in the city.

High-Speed, Low-Speed
In order to embrace diversity and cater to different user groups, UNStudio’s urban vision identified and considered six types of social units during the configuration of different neighbourhoods within the Xingdong New Area. These units are categorised based on age groups and rhythm, or pace of life, ranging from high-energy, fast-paced living to low-energy, slow-paced living.

description:
In recent decades, Indonesia’s capital of Jakarta has developed into a city with a cosmopolitan spirit and an international outlook. UNStudio’s interpretation of a new high-rise tower for this bustling metropolis takes into account the city’s future-proofing ambitions, whilst providing balanced building that honours the skyline.

Located on the intersection of the city’s two most-important streets (Sudirman and Gatot Subroto), the development features a memorable silhouette that will make it a landmark for Jakarta. With its slim profile and towering height, the design plays with geometry transformation and uses expressive markings, seamless details and a calm palette of materials to create a timeless and recognisable skyscraper.

Inspired by human movement and touch, the design embraces raw local materials while experimenting with the latest technology. Its most iconic feature is the SKY FOREST, a green core running up the centre of the tower, which sets a novel benchmark of positive urban impact and circular ecology. As a future-proof development, this indoor forest is just one of the sustainable features included in our design to address the issues of a lack of green space and air pollution in Jakarta.
title: Mangkuluhur City Tower II
concepts:
Vertical Neighbourhoods
Our ambition with the design is to shape an attractive, lively, mixed-use and economically meaningful high-rise space, which allows for unexpected encounters and extreme escapism.

Across the 350-metre-high tower we included numerous programmes, including a 2,500-capacity ballroom, an observation deck, 58 levels of offices, 22 levels of apartments as well as space for a hotel and parking. In order to encourage a sense of community in the space, we created public spaces for each programme within the building, all served by the SKY FOREST.

The facade has an overlapping texture to create shadow play and a finer reading when in close proximity, while the building lands onto the site with a gesture that echoes the geometry of the forest amenity area and repurposes it as an open and welcoming portal towards the ground floor lobby.

The SKY FOREST
The building framework for the Jakarta Tower was designed around the iconic SKY FOREST, a green core inspired by the surrounding landscape. Living up to its name, the indoor forest is a space of wonder and excitement, filled with lush, tropical trees and vegetation that is integrated into the architecture.

Our intention for this striking feature is to create a “second ground” in the sky, not only serving as the most prominent element of the tower but also setting a new paradigm of positive urban impact and circular ecology. Functionally, we designed an urban yet tropical park for residents where they can enjoy nature and the mezzanine of shared amenities, including a fully equipped gym. It also serves an essential function in the air circulation and purification in the building (see environmental responsibilities below).

Sustainability and Environmental Responsibility
The facade: In order to optimise sustainable constructions in the future, buildings should no longer be seen as mere energy saving or energy efficient structures. New technologies enable us to change buildings into energy harvesting vehicles with enhanced aesthetics and operability.

Solar Visuals, a revolutionary new cladding material brought to you by UNStudio’s daughter company UNSense, TNO and printing specialist TS Visuals, allowed for the building to be transformed into a battery without losing aesthetic appeal.

Using a patented dot printing software technology, Solar Visuals is capable of translating images into a setup of dots of different coverage ratios, controlling colour, contrast, brightness and a degree of randomness in the final effect. In doing so, it allows for these solar panels to be fully customised, creating visually appealing opportunities for large-scale energy production in the built environment.

The SKY FOREST: The tower’s green core is an integral component in our approach to purifying the air within the development. Acting as a natural smog filtration system, the indoor forest is paired with state-of-the-art technology located in the plant room below to create a system that will clean the air and circulate it throughout the entire building.

The core: Grey water from the hotel and residential components of the design will be treated and cleaned on site through packaged systems with living machines. All recycled greywater will be used to irrigate outdoor and indoor greenery, and for sanitary use in the office and podium spaces.
Programme: Mixed-use tower (Office, Residential, Hotel, Observation Deck)

description:
With its strong emphasis on the local ecology, the surrounding infrastructure and post-industrial heritage, our masterplan for Budapest’s South Gate is a campus for life-long learning that will provide fertile ground for existing and future communities to flourish, grow and thrive in the heart of the Hungarian capital.

For this competition, we teamed up with Germany’s Ramboll Studio Dreiseitl and the UK’s Buro Happold to develop a vision for a new urban campus and a catalyst for innovation in this buzzing European metropolis.

Ranked as one of the most-livable cities in Central Europe, and one of the most-visited cities in the world, we designed an innovative public space for the future of knowledge, sports and health in an environment that celebrates the rich cultural and historical background of the site.
title: Budapest South Gate Masterplan
keywords: A Synergy of Ecology and Community
concepts:
The Blue City
Our main concept revolves around the establishment of the Blue City, a synthesis of water and technology.

The site, located just south of Budapest’s city centre, bears a strong relationship to the neighbouring Danube river. This mighty waterway has frequently overflowed into the site previously, but instead of cordoning off the river with embankments or levees, our proposal involves a strategy for the natural formation of wetlands in order to benefit from the surrounding water in the area.

The changing water levels are beneficial for a wide variety of ecological zones. A network of streams, fish ramps, wetlands and water filtering foliage would allow nature to flourish and allow for the return of local wildlife. The blue-green infrastructure is developed on a sponge city model, to ensure the mitigation of rain and flooding events.

A skywalk, hovering above the area, does not interfere with natural processes. In this way, the waterfront becomes transformed into a rich ecological habitat and a prime destination throughout the year.
The second aspect of the Blue City concept focuses on the implementation of a technological layer. Local heritage is revitalised in order to serve future needs. The old railway tracks are transformed into a smart spine with self-driving cars and electrical charging station, whilst the Wholesale Market Hall is converted into a startup-hub with innovation plazas of various themes.
All together, these elements of the masterplan serve public life and a proactive generation that is committed to driving positive change for Budapest.

A Synergy of Ecology and Community
With over 40 colleges and universities located in the city, this lively capital has notable innovation capabilities as a technology and business incubator.

Our masterplan for Budapest’s South Gate accommodates 12,000 students, 4,000 members of young families and enables 20,000 work places for new businesses. This is combined with a 77-hectare-park for top athletes, and is all created in synergy with the local ecology and wildlife.

Large parts of the programme are linked to water and ecology. The functions of the sports park for example are embedded within the landscape, whilst the student city has an active boulevard along the canal, and the local heritage and residential areas are surrounded by parklands that host a broad range of social functions.

Seven Unique Neighbourhoods
Our masterplan proposal tackles the large scale of the site by developing seven distinctive yet interconnected neighbourhoods, which each celebrate their own unique identity and expression: the active sports park, the riparian ecological promenade, the heritage & innovation neighbourhood, the events district, the Danubius gateway, the urban retreat and the extended city.
Each zone has a specific anchor point that activates its natural surrounding with a diverse and cohesive set of programming. A meandering path binds each zone together allowing for clear future-proof phasing & accessibility to all throughout the masterplan.
Large car-free zones, social courtyards, parklands and a network of decentralised fitness and sport activities together facilitate a healthy lifestyle, nudging towards better decision making through spatial design and accessibility, to both the broader community and the sports elite.
The plan builds on research that indicates that zip codes are more important than genetic codes, meaning our surroundings we live and grow up in are trumping the base genetic code we start with. Ecology, livability, community are therefore all threads in the fabric of health the masterplan aims to weave to ensure future citizens and athletes will thrive.
Client: KKBK Kiemelt Kormányzati Beruházások Központja Nonprofit Zrt. (KKBK Centre of Key Government Investments Nonprofit Plc.)

description: Both Siemens and Berlin are transforming. In order to take advantage of its competitive edge as a creative, young city, and in order to bolster its position as a competitive brand, both Berlin and Siemens must provide agile, flexible and unique environments that can attract talent, while ensuring a sustainable and healthy lifestyle.
title: Siemensstadt 2.0 Masterplan
keywords: A Smart Ecological Framework – the Siemens Zigzag
concepts:
Creating a Unique Urban Identity
The plan pays special attention to public spaces, streets, green spaces and plazas, and to shared public buildings, making them safe and inclusive to all ages and genders. By celebrating historic buildings such as Verwaltungsgebauede, Schaltwerkhallen and Schaltwerkhochhaus while also introducing new urban elements into the development, the plan becomes the point of convergence between the past and the future, defining its urban identity urban as a transition between new and old.

A Smart Ecological Framework – the Siemens Zigzag
Responding directly to the ecological challenges of the site and its surrounding urban environment, the proposal outlines an ecological framework that revitalises nature on site and offsets industrial and urban development impacts. The ecological spine – the Siemens Zigzag, is an inclusive public space that serves as an ecological engine that includes trees and flowerbeds, water retention ponds and urban gardens. As such, it invites a rich, biodiverse host of pollinators and fauna into the site, while creating a destination for leisure and sports. The Zigzag also functions as the Smart backbone of the development, providing an independent data infrastructure that supports its mobility services, and its users at home and at work.
Programme: Residential, office/labs, Sports and Recreation, Retail, Hospitality, Education, Urban Farm, smart grid

description:
Xintiandi Plaza is located in the heart of Shanghai, along the well-known Huai Hai Road, and functions as an entrance gate to the buzzing Xintiandi area. Huai Hai Road and Xintiandi are fast becoming the most popular and famous shopping and entertainment areas in Shanghai, forming as they do both a local and an international retail destination.

Xintiandi Plaza is designed to provide a lifestyle destination for Shanghai’s young professionals. Combining retail, restaurants and themed spaces, all arranged in a novel organisation, Xintiandi Plaza steps away from the typical mall and towards a vertical city centre layout that provides opportunities for shopping, strolling, eating, gathering and relaxing.
title: Xintiandi Plaza
External Team:
Advisors
Local Design Institute: Tianhua
Facade: Inhabit
Lighting: ag licht / LEOX
Landscape: TianHua landscape
Interior Design shop drawings: DPDI

Photography
© Terrence Zhang
concepts:
Gateway to Xintiandi
In collaboration with Shui On Land – owners of both the Shui On Plaza and the Xintiandi developments – a strategy was established to turn the Shui On plaza into the gateway to the Xintiandi area, thereby enabling a transition and fusion of the international high-end fashion street Huai Hai Road and the traditional small scale Shikumen architecture lifestyle and F&B area.

The main concept for the Xintiandi Plaza design is to compile and compose these differing local characteristics within one building. This is achieved by stacking them vertically to create a landscape of different experiences. These experiences will be placed within the building envelope in key positions that are visible from the street, thereby allowing a glimpse of the activities taking place within and blurring the boundaries between the inside and outside space.

Inside the mall, elements of outdoor street life are mixed with lifestyle retail features and are distributed throughout the building. Resembling a leisurely stroll outside, this organisation encourages the visitor to wander through and explore the different levels of the building, where retail spaces follow an open layout and are punctuated with small kiosks.

Banded inside-out
The cylindrical tower geometry from the north-west corner of the existing building gives rise to the idea of undulating bands that define the building and determine the breakdown of the volume. These bands further create terraces and connect to the plaza and the street level. In the interior, the bands form atria and create a variety of activity spaces. Exterior and interior space are therefore controlled by the bands, which connect programme and activities by seamlessly moving through the facade layer and continuing into the interior.

In addition to this horizontal interconnectivity, several spaces are also connected in a vertical direction. The sunken plaza located towards Huai Hai Road connects the street level to the basement metro entry, while stacked balconies connect the ground level all the way to the roof garden. All platforms, terraces and outdoor spaces are planted with lush vegetation in order to create a new green urban landscape for this vertical city centre concept.

Facade
Matching the existing stone facade of the building - which will remain on the tower levels - and referencing the Shikumen brick used in Xintiandi, the dominant solid material used in the facade is terracotta. The high quality metallic finish of the terracotta tiles complements the glamourous atmosphere on Huai Hai Road. The use of the latest production techniques also ensures that the tiles form a very strong and durable facade material.

Interior
Bringing the outside landscape into the inside of the building creates a natural, organic effect, which is also evident in the interior design. Here the magnolia - Shanghai’s patron flower – is applied as a recurring motif. At the numerous access points to the mall, this flower motif is integrated into the backlit ceilings and is reimagined for use throughout the building, with columns inspired by the magnolia reaching all the way to the top of the building. These ‘flower columns’ are the central design feature of the mall and provide the visual connection between the different levels and spaces in the interior.

Two voids cut through the building volume and allow for a generous influx of natural daylight and ample views, which open up all the way from the second basement level to the top floor. The main diagonal void includes several plateaus that strengthen the idea of nature and organic structures when seen from below. Viewed from above they reveal flexibly programmable retail spaces.

The escalator void organises the vertical circulation and orientation. It creates view lines across the different levels and facilitates an unobstructed view column from the ground floor up to the skylight. The spiraling handrail surrounding the void guides the visitor to the next escalator. It further connects the voids and the different visitor routes, while carrying people through the building past a variety of activities and the magnolia columns. Finally, it culminates with the top level garden dining experience and the roof top garden.

From both inside and out, the experience of Xintiandi Plaza will become a memorable one along Huai Hai road, acting as a stand-alone lifestyle retail experience, as well as the gateway to Xintiandi.

description:
Will offices still exist in 50 years’ time? UNStudio’s Futures team, together with Swiss furniture brand USM, has designed a theatrical installation to reflect shifting boundaries between work and domesticity, now and in the future.

UNStudio’s Futures team was commissioned to explore changes taking place within the world of work, understand how these affect USM and identify opportunities for the future. Way back in 1930, economist John Maynard Keynes predicted that, by the early 21st century, advances in technology would lead to an “age of leisure and abundance” in which people might work 15 hour weeks.

Well, it didn’t exactly turn out that way. Work rules our lives today more than ever, and technology allows work to invade our leisure time. As digital nomads we are increasingly mobile, ready to set up office wherever we are. Cafés resemble living rooms, restaurants feel like home kitchens, and co-working spaces have replaced the home office.

USM’s booth marks the beginning of a long-term exploration for the company. UNStudio’s design explodes the spaces in which we live, using the USM modular system as a platform to support an absurd hybrid of domestic and office environments hidden within four floating chambers: the Dining Room, the Bedroom, the Bathroom and the Home Office. Being highly sustainable, the single parts of the booth can be reused for the next project after Milan.

Over the past few years, it has become conventional wisdom that automation, along with advances in artificial intelligence, have put us on the path to a jobless future. But all may not be doom and gloom. With the eradication of ‘bad jobs’ we can focus on finding meaning in our working lives. How can we learn more at work? How can we play?

A question posed in each room prompts us to reflect on the human qualities which differentiate us from machines and invites visitors to enter a dialogue with USM. Will the future workplace be designed around qualities rather than professions? Will work in the future take place in an office at all? Feedback from visitors will inspire a WorkHouse this summer in Berlin, where we’ll dive deeper into the idea of post-work and the need for lifelong learning to future-proof our careers.
title: USM Fair Stand, Salone del Mobile

description: The River City Carpet is inspired by the golden ratio – the ‘divine proportion’, or Phi – a number rooted in the architecture of our universe. Based on irrational numbers, it can be found in the engineering of all things natural, from the proportions of the human body to the structure of clouds. Equal parts common and exceptional, it is believed to be the most aesthetically pleasing and harmonious means of design.
title: River City Carpet

description:
The New Budapest Bridge, designed by UNStudio with Buro Happold Engineering, envisions a new gateway across the Danube river that will connect the neighbourhoods of Ujbuda and Csepel in the Hungarian capital. This new landmark for Budapest is both contemporary in design and innovative in structural form.

The bridge, a much-needed link over the river in the post-industrial southern area of Budapest will breathe new life into this up-and-coming area, and its design directly connects it to the urban DNA of its location.

Placed in this pivotal position, the bridge will knit into and build upon the already existing infrastructure in the area, creating a new public transport flow towards the city's south.

The bridge, which will span 220m, is a cable stayed structure with two steel pylons, and has been designed to create an elegant urban landmark to identify Budapest’s south, and its structural typology is unique for Budapest.
title: New Budapest Bridge
External Team:
Visualisations
(CGI): VA Render

Design Development
UNStudio
Ben van Berkel with Kristoph Nowak, Mircea Mogan, Ger Gijzen, Olga Kovrikova, Jan Schellhoff, Astrid Piber, Ayax Abreu Garcia, Wing Tang, Assaf Y. Cooremans, Dimitra Chatzipantazi, Sibilla Bonfanti
Engineering: BuroHappold and local partner CEH

Visualisations
(CGI) & Animation: ZOA
concepts:
It was essential that the bridge would be in harmony with Budapest - which owes much of its configuration to the surrounding landscape - and its future vision. It was also important that the bridge enable unobstructed views below and above the bridge deck. We wanted it to operate as a clear gateway to the city, like an inviting gesture of hands.
Ben van Berkel
Client: KKBK Kiemelt Kormányzati Beruházások Központja Nonprofit Zrt. (KKBK Centre of Key Government Investments Nonprofit Plc.) in collaboration with the Budapest Development Agency (BFK)
Programme: Traffic Bridge, with 4 car lanes, 2 tram lanes, 2 pedestrian and 2 bicycle lanes

description:
As learning transitions into a flexible, engaging and communal endeavor, our vision for UCD’s Future Campus transforms the current monofunctional campus into a ‘Marketplace of Innovation’. By reimagining the UCD campus as a vibrant space filled with agile spaces, the campus becomes a destination for learning, cultural and commerce: a green space of engagement.

As part of the Future Campus masterplan, a new Centre for Creative Design building was designed as a kick-starter for connectedness; it acts as a flexible platform that fosters serendipitous knowledge sharing and engenders a culture of engagement within UCD’s community. Located at a critical intersection near the campus entrance, this elevated building acts as a conduit for orientation. With its volume gesturing both outwards and upwards and with its lively interior on display for broader Dublin, the CCD truly becomes the heart of the Future Campus.
title: Future Campus, University College Dublin
Programme: Labs, studios, hospitality, residential, amenities, Creative Centre of Design Building

description: Hilversum Media Park 2030 - a new social ecosystem where innovation is a spectacle and culture is the heart of the community.
title: Hilversum Media Park 2030

description:
Our design proposal for the Challenge Museum, a unique museum in South Korea, creates an immersive and participatory experience for visitors, where exhibition and architecture blend with each other and with surrounding nature.
The building's massing and general site approach contrasts with urban conditions and provides restful, flexible outdoor spaces that encourage community engagement. With a compulsory two minute walk through farmland, the approach to the museum creates a grounded, organic experience for visitors, allowing them to feel connected with the earth.

The building programme is distributed over three floor levels. At the entrance to the building, visitors are guided towards an introductory space and then onward towards the exhibition floors. The museum unfolds itself above and below the visitor through a sequence of immersive Marine and Celestial spheres. These spheres overlap with one another throughout the museum, allowing users to explore the skies above them and the sea below through sceographic storytelling.

The ground floor has a focus on educational and public programmes. It has a porous design approach, with a porous facade that connects with the outdoor farm. The exhibition continues through to the second floor, with open views on the surrounding landscape, with the main body of the exhibition located on the third floor. Finally, the roof terrace connects the visitors again to the outdoors.

The museum provides a singular place for people to reflect on their own interests and talents and to imagine, with a fresh perspective, how they might step back out in the surrounding gardens and further into the wider world to become a pioneer that will create a meaningful positive impact.
title: The Challenge Museum
External Team:
Advisors
Exhibition Designer: Tellart Amsterdam
Cost Consultant: Turner & Townsend

Visualisations
UNStudio, Plompmozes
Diagrams: UNStudio, Tellart

description: The Socio-Technical City is a new urban vision for the ‘Central Innovation District’ (CID) square kilometer test site in The Hague. Our concept for the Socio-Technical City answers two of the biggest challenges facing cities - urbanisation and sustainability. How can an area like the CID, despite extremely high density in the future, become self-sufficient and energy-neutral? What does such an urban district look like? And how can we connect the required technology with the people who live and work there? In our future vision, The CID, which is triangulated by The Hague Central Station and two nearby stations, becomes a green, self-sufficient double-layered district, where a new urban layer of housing, offices, urban mobility and park-like public space is created over the existing train track infrastructure. The CID, having three intercity stations within walking distance of each other, presents an unprecedented opportunity to become Metropolitan Superhub; a system of closely linked terminals, comparable in size to Amsterdam Schiphol Airport.
title: Socio-Technical City of the Future
keywords: Gateways : catalysts for encounter and innovation
concepts:
Gateways : catalysts for encounter and innovation
With the elevated urban layer covering the existing railway tracks, our urban vision addresses the major transitional issues of our time through the creation of 'gateways': physical architectural interventions that create practical solutions to energy, circularity, mobility, climate adaptation, water management and food production. This series of gateways works to supply local low rise houses with geothermal energy, provide high rise buildings with solar power, create urban irrigation systems, produce drinking water and reuse water to supply local water features. While having a practical function, the gateways also have a social purpose, becoming bridges that connect neighbourhoods, community gardens, urban farms, co-working spaces and start up spaces. In this way, the Socio-Technical City bridges the gap between infrastructure and technology on the one hand, and quality of life and social well-being on the other.
Client: BNA, gemeente Den Haag, Ministerie BZK, Ministerie I&W, TUDelft, Vereniging Deltametropool

description:
Our proposal for the Dutch pavilion at the 2020 Expo in Dubai is structured around three pillars: Energy, Water and Food.
The pavilion, located in the Sustainability section of the Expo, consists of exhibition spaces, a facade, all supporting facilities and a Dune landscape.
title: Dutch/Dubai 2020 Expo Pavilion

description:
Textured and transparent, laced and illuminated, the brick pixelation Facade at the P.C. Hooftstraat 140-142 embodies the intricate, crafted details epitomised by couture clothing. Cast stainless steel bricks with glass inlays pixelate together along this partially transparent facade to create a distinctive shopfront experience on one of Amsterdam’s best-known streets.

The P.C. Hooftstraat is famous for its high-end boutiques and design shops, situated between the Museum Quarter, the Vondelpark and the Oud-Zuid neighbourhood. Shops along this street are a testament to Dutch design, creativity, high-end clothing and art. UNStudio’s renovation brought two separate buildings together to become one retail space, making The Brick Pixelation one of the largest retail spaces along the P.C. Hooftstraat.
title: P.C. Hooftstraat 140-142
External Team:
Advisors
Executive Architect: Architectenburo Dik Smeding BV
Facade Engineer: ARUP
Main contractor: Jan Vet b.v.

Photography
© Eva Bloem
concepts:
While the finished result is sensitively subtle, much experimentation was undertaken to find the correct brick size, transparency and lighting components that could create the appropriate effect on the surroundings. Although the overall sizes of the stainless steel bricks are the same as typical bricks, by tapering and softening the edges, the stainless steel bricks have a refined and intricately detailed appearance, with manually glued glass inlays.
The stainless steel bricks are cast in different sizes, following a similar pattern to the traditional brick facade on the upper levels. The individual stainless steel bricks are precisely mounted onto larger steel frames, then installed on site. Operable glass windows behind the steel brick facade allow for maintenance and cleaning.
The residential entrance door is composed of the same stainless steel bricks, but with an opaque glass inlay, ensuring privacy in the apartment entrance area. The stainless steel door handle and doorbell are also custom designed to integrate into the overall facade appearance.
The white steel window frames continue into the interior. Slanting the glass panels emphasises the dynamic of the white frames, a detail which is also continued in the smaller first floor windows.
Programme: Facade design: Concept Design – Construction supervision

description: Designed by Jan van der Laan and opened to the public with great fanfare in 1952, the C&A building was long held in high regard. However numerous alterations were made during its lifespan and the building is no longer considered dominant today. The modern addition of large, eye-catching entrances to underground bicycle parking facilities have also obstructed views to the building, with the result that it can no longer adequately express its identity, nor display a clear and recognisable storefront.
title: 18 Septemberplein
UNStudio Team: Jacques van Wijk and Alexander Kalachev Hans Kooij
External Team:
Advisors
Project management: bbn adviseurs, Houten
Structure: SWINN, Gouda
Installations: W4Y adviseurs, Harderwijk
Architecture: Van Manen, Noordwijk
Glass structures: ABT, Delft
Light design glassboxes: Arnout Meijer Studio, Amsterdam

Contractors, suppliers
General contractor: Stam + De Koning Bouw, Eindhoven
Glassbox contractor: Si-X, Benthuizen (Wout Hoogendoorn, Andre Molenaar, Martijn Leeyen)
Glassbox glass supplier; Thiele Glas, Wermsdorf (D)
Glass crown and aluminium panels: Sorba Projects bv, Winterswijk
concepts:
An experience of light
Reflectivity and sheen are added to the facade through the ambitious construction of four large glass structures. At 5.5 meters wide, 7 meters high and weighing 3000kg each, these illuminated windows appear to float on the surface of the monumental facade. This effect was achieved through a close collaboration between ABT, Si-X and UNStudio, which resulted in the creation of interlocking and glued connections that form an ‘invisible’ support and mounting system.
This type and scale of glass facade construction has never before been realised in the Netherlands. In order to make the glued construction possible at such a large scale, the team undertook one a half years of extensive research - and of trial and error - before finally finding a solution that could provide the level of craftsmanship and engineering precision required.

Glass Boxes
Angled at 10 degrees to maximise visual connections at street level, the glass structures are illuminated by LED lighting – designed by the Dutch artist Arnout Meijer - which is reflected and diffused by a thin film on the inside of the glass. Optical effects created by this film form patterns of light, which appear to alter as people move across the square. As such, the original design motif of protruding glass windows is used to emphasise the heritage of the C&A Store, whilst strongly identifying it with The City of Light.

description: For the Techtextil ‘Living in Space’ exhibition UNStudio and MDT-tex have created, Prototype II, a modular shelter which envisions how we might one day live on the moon or on Mars. The design is inspired by foldable structures and the need for lightweight and compact transport into space. In the Techtextil installation the self-supporting pavilion serves as a space in which guests can experience a trip to Mars in virtual reality - as represented by co-exhibitors the European Space Agency (ESA) and the German Aerospace Centre (DLR).

description:
Our vision for the Vertical Campus at Europaplatz creates a transparent working environment in the heart of Berlin. This is an inviting architectural design that is in close communion with its surroundings, creating an office landscape that is as diverse and accessible as Berlin itself.
As a structure, the Vertical Campus makes a distinction within the urban landscape, becoming the gateway to the new Europaquarter opposite the city’s main train station. This unique location and identity is an opportunity for the structure to open out towards the city, employees and citizens alike.
The internal setup of the Vertical Campus creates a framework where different working preferences of individual cultures, generations and personalities meet and co-exist. A diverse range of reset capsules, collaboration zones, concentration pockets and exterior spaces shape the background to a new, enriching working environment.
From the inside out, accessibility, identity and diversity form the corner stones for this urban architectural design in an exciting new quarter of Berlin.
title: Vertical Campus, Europaplatz
External Team:
Advisors
MEP, Structure, Facade: BuroHappold Engineering
Sustainability: EinsPlus
Visualisations: Sonaar

description: Our design proposal for the Limassol Hotel and Residential building is a future-proof, user-centric approach to living. Unlike typical high-rise developments that place the tower behind the plinth, our proposal places the tower at the front - making the most of its sea, mountain and historic city views. Kinks are introduced into the massing to accentuate exposure, while a shaded passageway connects the two sides of the site.

description:
The Alba truffle slicer, named to tribute the home of the White Truffle, celebrates an age-old culinary ritual. The accessory is designed to combine sculpted form with functionality; twisting steel evokes the intertwining roots where truffles grow, while the curved profile and 18° angle between emphasises the ergonomics of the grip, reduces pressure on the wrist and distributes weight evenly to produce the perfect slice. An adjustment mechanism allows the user to vary the thickness of the slices from 0 to 3 millimetres, and allows the user to completely close the blade so the utensil can be stored away safely. ‘Alba’ is the two-year end product of the “De Truffle” workshop that was launched in 2015 by Alessi, The National Centre for Truffle Studies and the International White Truffle Fair of Alba. At this workshop, fifteen designers were briefed to develop functional solutions for a utensil that has been used in kitchens for 300 years. From the fifteen designs that were developed over this period, Alessi chose to produce the ‘Alba’ truffle slicer designed by Ben van Berkel/UNStudio, taking account of technical feasibility, aesthetics and poetic force. ‘Alba’ is a functional table top microsculpture that offers a new aesthetic for slicing and serving the rare Alba White Truffle.

Alberto Alessi: “Subject to the assessment of the skilled Selection Committee, to the opinion of the public and to their technical feasibility; the one which was chosen is: Alba, designed by the Dutch architect Ben van Berkel who […] had a brilliant insight by bringing the concept back to the primordial typological reference of the item itself: the Plane.”

The prototypes and concepts developed for the “De Truffle” workshop will be exhibited at the “De Truffle. Alessi Design meets the Alba White Truffle” exhibition at Palazzo Banca d’Alba until Nov 26th 2017.
title: 'Alba' Truffle Slicer
External Team:
Alessi
Alessi with consultancy of Centro Nazionale Studi Tartufo and Fiera Internazionale del Tartufo Bianco d'Alba
